vSource.nodeDescription: Text: The Vermillion River Observatory was constructed thanks to the work of George Swenson, a professor of astronomy and electrical engineering. Swenson was in charge of creating an interdisciplinary program in radio astronomy research. The telescopes (a model of which is found in the case) helped scientists catalog interstellar data. They then used this data to analyze the molecular structure of interstellar gas.

vTarget.nodeDescription:
i. Measuring a star’s brightness would take hours of observation and calculations. Astronomy professor Joel Stebbins in collaboration with physics professors F.C. Brown and Jakob Kunz would develop the photoelectric photometer which would use electricity to help simplify this process. 
 
 ii. Stebbins credited his wife as the driving force for this idea. When they were first married she would sometimes go to the observatory with him to help him get his work done faster so they could spend more time together. He told her one day they would be able to do this much faster with electricity and from then on she encouraged him to discover this method. A couple of months later he went to a physics open house where F.C. Brown had a demonstration of a selenium cell. Stebbins worked with Brown to create a selenium cell photometer.
 
 iii. While the selenium cell photometer helped discover five new eclipsing binary stars, Stebbins felt it was not strong enough. He was introduced to Jakob Kunz, who had been working to improve photoelectric cells. They collaborated to create and continually refine the photoelectric photometer. This development allowed for stebbins to better research variable stars and he was able to measure diameters and masses more accurately than any other instrument had been able to provide up to that point.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Node descriptionSometimes an innovation can be used for multiple purposes, some not even imagined while creating it. The electrostatic gyroscope was created at the University of Illinois by Howard Knoebel. The electrostatic gyroscope was initially invented to be used in submarines - which needed an instrument that would not need to be calibrated since it would be submerged for up to 30 days at a time. This device though would later be used in satellites to help them navigate space.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Today, the University of Illinois continues its interdisciplinary and collaborative approach to astronomy. One current project is the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope. This project is an international collaboration with the telescope located in Chile and the data being stored in Champaign Urbana. The National Center for Supercomputing Applications will store the 10 years worth of data, collecting about 20 terabytes of image data a night beginning in 2023. The data will be processed into reports as well as alerting researchers in near-real time of new and unexpected astronomical events.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Dr. Robert Wilhemson was the first to create a digital animation of a thunderstorm (it was even nominated for an Academy Award in 1989 and won 14 other awards). He later developed an animation of a tornado forming from a thunderstorm. These technological advancements led to a new process to help with storm predictions. Computer models are now widely used to help understand storm movements.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Today, the University of Illinois continues its interdisciplinary and collaborative approach to astronomy. One current project is the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope. This project is an international collabThe faculty and staff at NCSA has worked to develop models and visualizations of space. One recurrent visualization is the black hole. A prominent figure in Science Fiction, the black hole has a lot of unknowns. But through study and research of the space around the black hole, as well as other measurements, NCSA has been able to visualize and create artistic renderings of ways to show how a black hole operates. Examples include numeric models to detect gravitational waves from black holes colliding,oration with the telescope located in Chile and the data being stored in Champaign Urbana. The National Center for Supercomputing Applications will store the 10 years worth of data, collecting about 20 terabytes of image data a night beginning in 2023. The data will be processed into reports as well as alerting researchers in near-real time of new and unexpected astronomical events.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Another example of where Art and Science come together is Professor stephen Cartright's data sculptures. Cartright keeps different data sets related to himself including data points such as his longitude and latitude, personal habits, and the weather around him. He then takes these data sets and turns them into sculptures or digital media to showcase this data in new ways. One of his most recent works invites the public to input their own data on where their ancestors have lived to show how people move.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Steve Hilberg new method for comparing weather data
vTarget.nodeDescription: Professor Steve Hilberg collaborated with meteorologist Barbara Mayes Bousted (National Weather Service) to create the Accumulated Winter Season Severity Index. They take four variables, which are the daily maximum and minimum temperatures, snowfall and snow depth, and assign each a value. The scores are then totaled for each day and are added to the index. The index is useful in analyzing trends over one season as well as comparing the current season to past winters. It helps to look at patterns of severity of winter, with the ability to look at more specific geographical areas and can help assist with studying changes in climate.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Tony Wong Large Magellanic Cloud to look at star formation
vTarget.nodeDescription: Astronomy professor Tony Wong and a group of researchers were able to map how stars are born in the nearest star-forming galaxy. Wong and his team hope to use this information to understand our own galaxy. Wong used the Large Magellanic Cloud (nearby galaxy) to study, as it it tilted face-on. This tilt makes it easier for astronomers to study star formation. Based on what they are able to see, they decided to focus on molecular clouds as a base for star formation. They used a telescope in Australia to look at the Large Magellanic Cloud straight on to view those molecular clouds.

nodeAttributes.Possible object: telescope or LMC (LMC image in link)

vSource.nodeLabel: Tracking Sputnik I's Orbit with minitrack inferometer
vSource.nodeDescription: George Swenson obtained the minitrack inferometer for members of the Illinois Astronomical Society to track Sputnik I's orbit on October 4, 1957. On the night in question, the inferometer was able to get measurements of Sputnik and were able to use Doppler Radar data. Members of the department used the data from the Doppler and inferometer to study its orbit. This data helped advance sateillite-based astronomical research and was helped with grants from the National Research Council, NASA, and the Air Force.

vTarget.nodeDescription: The University of Illinois has been studying the relationship between nature and humans since its earliest days. From 1884 to 1921, Stephen Forbes was a professor in zoology and entomology who mostly studied insects, birds, fish and crustaceans. His major area of focus was the interactions between species and how these interactions affected the agricultural industry. His publications were some of the earliest work in what is now known as the field of ecology and he is considered as one of the founders of the formal field. vSource.nodeDescription:
"Tami Bond's research focuses on different properties of carbon-containing particles, which can contribute to carbon emissions. This research places an emphasis on the chemistry related to climate change and how climate change, while caused by long-lasting pollutants, is also caused by pollutants that show their effects within a few days. One of Bond's specific focuses are the emissions starting from the industrial revolution, showing a long-term study of pollution and its relationship to climate change.
"

vSource.nodeDescription: As greenhouse gases and carbon dioxide continue to increase in our atmosphere, there has been much research done on what the possible impacts will be to our food supply. A multidisciplinary team at the University of Illinois was the first to conduct outdoor research on the effects of increased carbon dioxide on crops in a project called the Soybean Free Air Concentration Enrichment (SoyFACE). Previous studies have grown crops inside greenhouses to study what the changes in atmosphere may entail. For SoyFACE, Llarge octagonal plots are established with the ability to release higher concentrations of carbon dioxide and ozone on any side of the plot. This helps account for wind carrying the gases across the plot. This innovative way allows for crops to be grown with typical conditions but with future atmospheric conditions.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Steve Hilberg new method for comparing weather data
vTarget.nodeDescription: Professor Steve Hilberg collaborated with meteorologist Barbara Mayes Bousted (National Weather Service) to create the Accumulated Winter Season Severity Index. They take four variables, which are the daily maximum and minimum temperatures, snowfall and snow depth, and assign each a value. The scores are then totaled for each day and are added to the index. The index is useful in analyzing trends over one season as well as comparing the current season to past winters. It helps to look at patterns of severity of winter, with the ability to look at more specific geographical areas and can help assist with studying changes in climate.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Another example of where Art and Science come together is Professor stephen Cartright's data sculptures. Cartright keeps different data sets related to himself including data points such as his longitude and latitude, personal habits, and the weather around him. He then takes these data sets and turns them into sculptures or digital media to showcase this data in new ways. One of his most recent works invites the public to input their own data on where their ancestors have lived to show how people move.

They then used this data to analyze the molecular structure of interstellar gas.

vSource.nodeLabel: Global Warming effects on the Houma Tribe (Shanondora Billiot’s research)
vSource.nodeDescription: Shanondora BIllet went to Louisiana's Gulf Coast to interview members from the United Houma Nation to look at how the destruction of the coast has affected their lives and worldview. After being vetted by leaders of the tribe, BIllet was able to see that the tribe, which makes its living via the water (fishing, shrimping, trapping, etc.) and had to change how they made their living. With the new changes to the coast and to the water, older members of the Houma tribe find it difficult to pass on their traditions to youngermembers, causing distress. This climate change and destruction of the coast has caused a nation to reevaluate their way of life and their traditions.

vTarget.nodeDescription: The University of Illinois has been studying the relationship between nature and humans since its earliest days. From 1884 to 1921, Stephen Forbes was a professor in zoology and entomology who mostly studied insects, birds, fish and crustaceans. His major area of focus was the interactions between species and how these interactions affected the agricultural industry. His publications were some of the earliest work in what is now known as the field of ecology and he is considered as one of the founders of the formal field. Looking at how animals and humans have an impact on each other’s environments, habits, and culture is also an important part of climate change research currently taking place.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Tony Wong Large Magellanic Cloud to look at star formation
vTarget.nodeDescription: Astronomy professor Tony Wong and a group of researchers were able to map how stars are born in the nearest star-forming galaxy. Wong and his team hope to use this information to understand our own galaxy. Wong used the Large Magellanic Cloud (nearby galaxy) to study, as it it tilted face-on. This tilt makes it easier for astronomers to study star formation. Based on what they are able to see, they decided to focus on molecular clouds as a base for star formation. They used a telescope in Australia to look at the Large Magellanic Cloud straight on to view those molecular clouds.

nodeAttributes.Possible object: telescope or LMC (LMC image in link)

vSource.nodeLabel: Religious Figures talking about climate change: StewardshipNode name
vSource.nodeDescription: Psychology graduate student Faith Shin conducted research on how different messages within Christianity were linked to how people viewed and responded to climate change. Shin found that messages linked to stewardship (God commands humans to take care of the Earth) often resulted in Christians viewing climate change concern as a moral imperative. This is compared to dominion beliefs, which advocate for the idea that God gives humans free reign. Dominion beliefs are linked tot lower concerncocnern for climate change. Shin conducted this research through having different groups read different articles including: Bible passages (either stewardship or dominion) or a control article. An interesting find is that while the stewardship articles showed an increase inmore moral concern about climate change, the dominion articles did not reduce moral concerns.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Node descriptionSometimes an innovation can be used for multiple purposes, some not even imagined while creating it. The electrostatic gyroscope was created at the University of Illinois by Howard Knoebel. The electrostatic gyroscope was initially invented to be used in submarines - which needed an instrument that would not need to be calibrated since it would be submerged for up to 30 days at a time. This device though would later be used in satellites to help them navigate space.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Dr. Robert Wilhemson was the first to create a digital animation of a thunderstorm (it was even nominated for an Academy Award in 1989 and won 14 other awards). He later developed an animation of a tornado forming from a thunderstorm. These technological advancements led to a new process to help with storm predictions. Computer models are now widely used to help understand storm movements.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Tracking Sputnik I's Orbit with minitrack inferometer
vTarget.nodeDescription: George Swenson obtained the minitrack inferometer for members of the Illinois Astronomical Society to track Sputnik I's orbit on October 4, 1957. On the night in question, the inferometer was able to get measurements of Sputnik and were able to use Doppler Radar data. Members of the department used the data from the Doppler and inferometer to study its orbit. This data helped advance sateillite-based astronomical research and was helped with grants from the National Research Council, NASA, and the Air Force.

vSource.nodeDescription: Researchers under Professor Jeff Trapp performed statistical analyses on historical weather data, showing that there was a link between tornadoes and the Arctic Sea. Largely, they found that there was a reduction in tornado activity, which they thought was linked to the melting of Arctic sea ice and how that ice controlled the jet stream. They found that there was a missing element in tornado formation (oftentimes, moisture was missing). Trapp and his team plan to use the data from their research to make predictions about hail and tornadoes.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Text: The Vermillion River Observatory was constructed thanks to the work of George Swenson, a professor of astronomy and electrical engineering. Swenson was in charge of creating an interdisciplinary program in radio astronomy research. The telescopes (a model of which is found in the case) helped scientists catalog interstellar data. They then used this data to analyze the molecular structure of interstellar gas.

vSource.nodeDescription: Researchers under Professor Jeff Trapp performed statistical analyses on historical weather data, showing that there was a link between tornadoes and the Arctic Sea. They found that there was a missing element in tornado formation (oftentimes, moisture was missing). Trapp and his team plan to use the data from their research to make predictions about hail and tornadoes.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Today, the University of Illinois continues its interdisciplinary and collaborative approach to astronomy. One current project is the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope. This project is an international collabThe faculty and staff at NCSA has worked to develop models and visualizations of space. One recurrent visualization is the black hole. A prominent figure in Science Fiction, the black hole has a lot of unknowns. But through study and research of the space around the black hole, as well as other measurements, NCSA has been able to visualize and create artistic renderings of ways to show how a black hole operates. Examples include numeric models to detect gravitational waves from black holes colliding,oration with the telescope located in Chile and the data being stored in Champaign Urbana. The National Center for Supercomputing Applications will store the 10 years worth of data, collecting about 20 terabytes of image data a night beginning in 2023. The data will be processed into reports as well as alerting researchers in near-real time of new and unexpected astronomical events.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Another example of where Art and Science come together is Professor stephen Cartright's data sculptures. Cartright keeps different data sets related to himself including data points such as his longitude and latitude, personal habits, and the weather around him. He then takes these data sets and turns them into sculptures or digital media to showcase this data in new ways. One of his most recent works invites the public to input their own data on where their ancestors have lived to show how people move.

vSource.nodeDescription: Researchers under Professor Jeff Trapp performed statistical analyses on historical weather data, showing that there was a link between tornadoes and the Arctic Sea. Largely, they found that there was a reduction in tornado activity, which they thought was linked to the melting of Arctic sea ice and how that ice controlled the jet stream. They found that there was a missing element in tornado formation (oftentimes, moisture was missing). vTarget.nodeLabel: Steve Hilberg new method for comparing weather data
vTarget.nodeDescription: Professor Steve Hilberg collaborated with meteorologist Barbara Mayes Bousted (National Weather Service) to create the Accumulated Winter Season Severity Index. They take four variables, which are the daily maximum and minimum temperatures, snowfall and snow depth, and assign each a value. The scores are then totaled for each day and are added to the index. The index is useful in analyzing trends over one season as well as comparing the current season to past winters. It helps to look at patterns of severity of winter, with the ability to look at more specific geographical areas and can help assist with studying changes in climate.

vSource.nodeDescription: Researchers under Professor Jeff Trapp performed statistical analyses on historical weather data, showing that there was a link between tornadoes and the Arctic Sea. Largely, they found that there was a reduction in tornado activity, which they thought was linked to the melting of Arctic sea ice and how that ice controlled the jet stream. They found that there was a missing element in tornado formation (oftentimes, moisture was missing). Trapp and his team plan to use the data from their research to make predictions about hail and tornadoes.

vTarget.nodeDescription: As greenhouse gases and carbon dioxide continue to increase in our atmosphere, there has been much research done on what the possible impacts will be to our food supply. A multidisciplinary team at the University of Illinois was the first to conduct outdoor research on the effects of increased carbon dioxide on crops in a project called the Soybean Free Air Concentration Enrichment (SoyFACE). Previous studies have grown crops inside greenhouses to study what the changes in atmosphere may entail. For SoyFACE, Llarge octagonal plots are established with the ability to release higher concentrations of carbon dioxide and ozone on any side of the plot. This helps account for wind carrying the gases across the plot. This innovative way allows for crops to be grown with typical conditions but with future atmospheric conditions.

nodeAttributes.Department: Plant Biology, crop sciences; agricultural and biological engineering; integrative biology, Natural Resources and envirnomental sciences

vSource.nodeLabel: People’s perceptions of climate change impacted by local weather
vSource.nodeDescription: Professor of Finance, Tatyana Deryugina, found through surveys that people think climate change is a problem if there are abnormalities in their local weather for two months or more, but not for only a few days or weeks. She argues that combating climate change is linked to individual perceptions of climate issues as opposed to societal views , which is why it is important to look at how individuals come to their views towards climate change. Based on her research, Deryugina found that people often didn't show a sense of urgency unless there were significant changes. People often paid more attention to local weather in forming their views of climate change and often times forget about larger occurrences like heat waves. These views impact how public policy is enacted and the timeline it is enacted in.

vSource.nodeDescription: Professor of Finance, Tatyana Deryugina, found through surveys that people think climate change is a problem if there are abnormalities in their local weather for two months or more, but not for only a few days or weeks. She argues that combating climate change is linked to individual perceptions of climate issues as opposed to societal views , which is why it is important to look at how individuals come to their views towards climate change. Based on her research, Deryugina found that people often didn't show a sense of urgency unless there were significant changes. People often paid more attention to local weather in forming their views of climate change and often times forget about larger occurrences like heat waves. These views impact how public policy is enacted and the timeline it is enacted in.

nodeAttributes.Possible object: image of survey or weather abnormalities

vTarget.nodeDescription: Researchers under Professor Jeff Trapp performed statistical analyses on historical weather data, showing that there was a link between tornadoes and the Arctic Sea. Largely, they found that there was a reduction in tornado activity, which they thought was linked to the melting of Arctic sea ice and how that ice controlled the jet stream. They found that there was a missing element in tornado formation (oftentimes, moisture was missing). Trapp and his team plan to use the data from their research to make predictions about hail and tornadoes.

vSource.nodeLabel: Peter Nardulli's study on climate change and the possible link to civil unrest
vSource.nodeDescription: Peter Nardulli with Buddy Peyton and Joseph Bajjalieh, used SPEED (a big data resource) to conducted research on climate change and civil unrest after weather-related climate change catastrophes. They found that areas where there waswho use violence prior to a climate change event were more likely to have increased violence after a natural disaster. The goal ofy wanted to focus on this research was to help fix policies surrounding civil unrest, and help leaders helping areas know how long unrest can last after a climate change event. To figure out this research, Nardulli and his team used a random sample of storms and floods and examined looked at data surrounding civil unrest in the affected areas to complete this research in certain cities affected by the climate change events.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Tony Wong Large Magellanic Cloud to look at star formation
vTarget.nodeDescription: Astronomy professor Tony Wong and a group of researchers were able to map how stars are born in the nearest star-forming galaxy. Wong and his team hope to use this information to understand our own galaxy. Wong used the Large Magellanic Cloud (nearby galaxy) to study, as it it tilted face-on. This tilt makes it easier for astronomers to study star formation. Based on what they are able to see, they decided to focus on molecular clouds as a base for star formation. They used a telescope in Australia to look at the Large Magellanic Cloud straight on to view those molecular clouds.

vTarget.nodeDescription: The University of Illinois has been studying the relationship between nature and humans since its earliest days. From 1884 to 1921, Stephen Forbes was a professor in zoology and entomology who mostly studied insects, birds, fish and crustaceans. His major area of focus was the interactions between species and how these interactions affected the agricultural industry. His publications were some of the earliest work in what is now known as the field of ecology and he is considered as one of the founders of the formal field. Looking at how animals and humans have an impact on each other’s environments, habits, and culture is also an important part of climate change research currently taking place.

"Tami Bond's research focuses on different properties of carbon-containing particles, which can contribute to carbon emissions. This research places an emphasis on the chemistry related to climate change and how climate change, while caused by long-lasting pollutants, is also caused by pollutants that show their effects within a few days. One of Bond's specific focuses are the emissions starting from the industrial revolution, showing a long-term study of pollution and its relationship to climate change.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Global Warming effects on the Houma Tribe (Shanondora Billiot’s research)
vTarget.nodeDescription: Shanondora BIllet went to Louisiana's Gulf Coast to interview members from the United Houma Nation to look at how the destruction of the coast has affected their lives and worldview. After being vetted by leaders of the tribe, BIllet was able to see that the tribe, which makes its living via the water (fishing, shrimping, trapping, etc.) and had to change how they made their living. With the new changes to the coast and to the water, older members of the Houma tribe find it difficult to pass on their traditions to youngermembers, causing distress. This climate change and destruction of the coast has caused a nation to reevaluate their way of life and their traditions.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Religious Figures talking about climate change: StewardshipNode name
vTarget.nodeDescription: Psychology graduate student Faith Shin conducted research on how different messages within Christianity were linked to how people viewed and responded to climate change. Shin found that messages linked to stewardship (God commands humans to take care of the Earth) often resulted in Christians viewing climate change concern as a moral imperative. This is compared to dominion beliefs, which advocate for the idea that God gives humans free reign. Dominion beliefs are linked tot lower concerncocnern for climate change. Shin conducted this research through having different groups read different articles including: Bible passages (either stewardship or dominion) or a control article. An interesting find is that while the stewardship articles showed an increase inmore moral concern about climate change, the dominion articles did not reduce moral concerns.

nodeAttributes.Observations: (solution of having people change their language)
nodeAttributes.Department: formaly a part of psychology but als uses Religion/ Linguistics

vSource.nodeLabel: Deke Weaver's art on tigers and effect of climate change
vSource.nodeDescription: Deke Weaver, professor of new media, created and starred in a show called TIGER from a five-part series called "The Unreliable Bestiary." In this show and this series, Weaver talks about famous tigers, such as Tony the Tiger and the tigers from the Jungle Book, as well as how humans interact with tigers. This was created to call attention to climate change and how it affects wildlife. To further comment on this, Weaver performed the show along the Mississippi River and its watershed to comment on migration as a result of climate change.

nodeAttributes.Possible object: costume from the show? (Weaver portrayed a ranger)
nodeAttributes.Observations: show providing a new way to look at climate change issues
nodeAttributes.College: College of Fine and Applied Arts
nodeAttributes.Department: Art and Design (Weaver is specifically New Media)

vSource.nodeDescription: Professor Emma Mercier and her research team created a new app called "Food for Thought" which tells children about the carbon footprint created by the food they eat. The app tells the nutritional data along with the carbon footprint. Mercier's goal is twofold: to help children be more "data literate" and learn more about the causes of climate change. To do this research, Mercier and her team videotaped children learning about climate change and their food carbon footprint. The focus on food was to look at what children have more control over, which makes climate change awareness and learning more accessible.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Text: The Vermillion River Observatory was constructed thanks to the work of George Swenson, a professor of astronomy and electrical engineering. Swenson was in charge of creating an interdisciplinary program in radio astronomy research. The telescopes (a model of which is found in the case) helped scientists catalog interstellar data. They then used this data to analyze the molecular structure of interstellar gas.

vTarget.nodeDescription:
i. Measuring a star’s brightness would take hours of observation and calculations. Astronomy professor Joel Stebbins in collaboration with physics professors F.C. Brown and Jakob Kunz would develop the photoelectric photometer which would use electricity to help simplify this process. 
 
 ii. Stebbins credited his wife as the driving force for this idea. When they were first married she would sometimes go to the observatory with him to help him get his work done faster so they could spend more time together. He told her one day they would be able to do this much faster with electricity and from then on she encouraged him to discover this method. A couple of months later he went to a physics open house where F.C. Brown had a demonstration of a selenium cell. Stebbins worked with Brown to create a selenium cell photometer.
 
 iii. While the selenium cell photometer helped discover five new eclipsing binary stars, Stebbins felt it was not strong enough. He was introduced to Jakob Kunz, who had been working to improve photoelectric cells. They collaborated to create and continually refine the photoelectric photometer. This development allowed for stebbins to better research variable stars and he was able to measure diameters and masses more accurately than any other instrument had been able to provide up to that point.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Node descriptionSometimes an innovation can be used for multiple purposes, some not even imagined while creating it. The electrostatic gyroscope was created at the University of Illinois by Howard Knoebel. The electrostatic gyroscope was initially invented to be used in submarines - which needed an instrument that would not need to be calibrated since it would be submerged for up to 30 days at a time. This device though would later be used in satellites to help them navigate space.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Today, the University of Illinois continues its interdisciplinary and collaborative approach to astronomy. One current project is the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope. This project is an international collaboration with the telescope located in Chile and the data being stored in Champaign Urbana. The National Center for Supercomputing Applications will store the 10 years worth of data, collecting about 20 terabytes of image data a night beginning in 2023. The data will be processed into reports as well as alerting researchers in near-real time of new and unexpected astronomical events.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Dr. Robert Wilhemson was the first to create a digital animation of a thunderstorm (it was even nominated for an Academy Award in 1989 and won 14 other awards). He later developed an animation of a tornado forming from a thunderstorm. These technological advancements led to a new process to help with storm predictions. Computer models are now widely used to help understand storm movements.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Tracking Sputnik I's Orbit with minitrack inferometer
vTarget.nodeDescription: George Swenson obtained the minitrack inferometer for members of the Illinois Astronomical Society to track Sputnik I's orbit on October 4, 1957. On the night in question, the inferometer was able to get measurements of Sputnik and were able to use Doppler Radar data. Members of the department used the data from the Doppler and inferometer to study its orbit. This data helped advance sateillite-based astronomical research and was helped with grants from the National Research Council, NASA, and the Air Force.

nodeAttributes.Current Faculty research: George Swenson, George McVitte, Stanley Wyatt, Ivan King

vTarget.nodeLabel: IMAX "A Beautiful Planet" with help from NCSA
vTarget.nodeDescription: The Ebert Symposium showed the film "A Beautiful Planet," which the NCSA helped create. The filmmakers collaborated with NCSA to create the opening and closing scenes of virtual intergalactic flight. The NCSA was able to create these scenes through scientific research. This film was shown as part of the "Empathy for the Universe: Storytelling and Data Visualization" tribute to Roger Ebert, a UIUC alum. This tribute also included an interview with astronaut Terry Virts and a variety of professors and alumni that discussed science data visualization in film.

vTarget.nodeDescription: As greenhouse gases and carbon dioxide continue to increase in our atmosphere, there has been much research done on what the possible impacts will be to our food supply. A multidisciplinary team at the University of Illinois was the first to conduct outdoor research on the effects of increased carbon dioxide on crops in a project called the Soybean Free Air Concentration Enrichment (SoyFACE). Previous studies have grown crops inside greenhouses to study what the changes in atmosphere may entail. For SoyFACE, Llarge octagonal plots are established with the ability to release higher concentrations of carbon dioxide and ozone on any side of the plot. This helps account for wind carrying the gases across the plot. This innovative way allows for crops to be grown with typical conditions but with future atmospheric conditions.

nodeAttributes.College: ACES/ LAS/ School of Integrative biology/ Institute for Genomic Biology
nodeAttributes.Department: Plant Biology, crop sciences; agricultural and biological engineering; integrative biology, Natural Resources and envirnomental sciences

"Tami Bond's research focuses on different properties of carbon-containing particles, which can contribute to carbon emissions. This research places an emphasis on the chemistry related to climate change and how climate change, while caused by long-lasting pollutants, is also caused by pollutants that show their effects within a few days. One of Bond's specific focuses are the emissions starting from the industrial revolution, showing a long-term study of pollution and its relationship to climate change.
"

nodeAttributes.Observations: (still need to do more research)
nodeAttributes.Department: Civil and Environmental Engineering; Affiliate faculty Atmospheric Sciences (also some Anthropology although not formally affiliated with the department)

vSource.nodeDescription: Professor Emma Mercier and her research team created a new app called "Food for Thought" which tells children about the carbon footprint created by the food they eat. The app tells the nutritional data along with the carbon footprint. Mercier's goal is twofold: to help children be more "data literate" and learn more about the causes of climate change. To do this research, Mercier and her team videotaped children learning about climate change and their food carbon footprint. The focus on food was to look at what children have more control over, which makes climate change awareness and learning more accessible.

nodeAttributes.Observations: link to University Laboratory High School

vTarget.nodeLabel: Global Warming effects on the Houma Tribe (Shanondora Billiot’s research)
vTarget.nodeDescription: Shanondora BIllet went to Louisiana's Gulf Coast to interview members from the United Houma Nation to look at how the destruction of the coast has affected their lives and worldview. After being vetted by leaders of the tribe, BIllet was able to see that the tribe, which makes its living via the water (fishing, shrimping, trapping, etc.) and had to change how they made their living. With the new changes to the coast and to the water, older members of the Houma tribe find it difficult to pass on their traditions to youngermembers, causing distress. This climate change and destruction of the coast has caused a nation to reevaluate their way of life and their traditions.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Religious Figures talking about climate change: StewardshipNode name
vTarget.nodeDescription: Psychology graduate student Faith Shin conducted research on how different messages within Christianity were linked to how people viewed and responded to climate change. Shin found that messages linked to stewardship (God commands humans to take care of the Earth) often resulted in Christians viewing climate change concern as a moral imperative. This is compared to dominion beliefs, which advocate for the idea that God gives humans free reign. Dominion beliefs are linked tot lower concerncocnern for climate change. Shin conducted this research through having different groups read different articles including: Bible passages (either stewardship or dominion) or a control article. An interesting find is that while the stewardship articles showed an increase inmore moral concern about climate change, the dominion articles did not reduce moral concerns.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Peter Nardulli's study on climate change and the possible link to civil unrest
vTarget.nodeDescription: Peter Nardulli with Buddy Peyton and Joseph Bajjalieh, used SPEED (a big data resource) to conducted research on climate change and civil unrest after weather-related climate change catastrophes. They found that areas where there waswho use violence prior to a climate change event were more likely to have increased violence after a natural disaster. The goal ofy wanted to focus on this research was to help fix policies surrounding civil unrest, and help leaders helping areas know how long unrest can last after a climate change event. To figure out this research, Nardulli and his team used a random sample of storms and floods and examined looked at data surrounding civil unrest in the affected areas to complete this research in certain cities affected by the climate change events.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Deke Weaver's art on tigers and effect of climate change
vTarget.nodeDescription: Deke Weaver, professor of new media, created and starred in a show called TIGER from a five-part series called "The Unreliable Bestiary." In this show and this series, Weaver talks about famous tigers, such as Tony the Tiger and the tigers from the Jungle Book, as well as how humans interact with tigers. This was created to call attention to climate change and how it affects wildlife. To further comment on this, Weaver performed the show along the Mississippi River and its watershed to comment on migration as a result of climate change.

nodeAttributes.Possible object: costume from the show? (Weaver portrayed a ranger)
nodeAttributes.Observations: show providing a new way to look at climate change issues
nodeAttributes.College: College of Fine and Applied Arts
nodeAttributes.Department: Art and Design (Weaver is specifically New Media)

vSource.nodeLabel: "Other Natures" book about Ancient Greek ethnographies
vSource.nodeDescription: Professor Clara Bosak-Schroder looks at ethnographies written by Herodotus and Diodorus to see how their works look in the context of current climate change issues. These ethnographies (ancient travelogues) look at differences in consumption, something that is more relevant now as we look to different things to eat in the wake of a changing climate. Bosak-Schroder thinks that these ethnographies can help current leaders find ways to view and fix climate change issues. She also focuses on how people are educated about climate issues, which is another way that these ancient words can help influence modern thinking.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Tony Wong Large Magellanic Cloud to look at star formation
vTarget.nodeDescription: Astronomy professor Tony Wong and a group of researchers were able to map how stars are born in the nearest star-forming galaxy. Wong and his team hope to use this information to understand our own galaxy. Wong used the Large Magellanic Cloud (nearby galaxy) to study, as it it tilted face-on. This tilt makes it easier for astronomers to study star formation. Based on what they are able to see, they decided to focus on molecular clouds as a base for star formation. They used a telescope in Australia to look at the Large Magellanic Cloud straight on to view those molecular clouds.

vTarget.nodeDescription: The University of Illinois has been studying the relationship between nature and humans since its earliest days. From 1884 to 1921, Stephen Forbes was a professor in zoology and entomology who mostly studied insects, birds, fish and crustaceans. His major area of focus was the interactions between species and how these interactions affected the agricultural industry. His publications were some of the earliest work in what is now known as the field of ecology and he is considered as one of the founders of the formal field. Looking at how animals and humans have an impact on each other’s environments, habits, and culture is also an important part of climate change research currently taking place.

vSource.nodeDescription: The Earth's critical zone is it's "living skin" that, when studied, looks at how different processes on Earth interact. Praveen Kumar does research on hydrology and its different processes. The critical zone helps us understand how interactions between water, air, life, and rock can be affected by human behavior. More specifically, the critical zone looks at how changing the Earth's surface can affect subsurface processes including waterflow and elements. Kumar's research into water is a key aspect of looking at the critical zone and it's link to climate change.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Node descriptionSometimes an innovation can be used for multiple purposes, some not even imagined while creating it. The electrostatic gyroscope was created at the University of Illinois by Howard Knoebel. The electrostatic gyroscope was initially invented to be used in submarines - which needed an instrument that would not need to be calibrated since it would be submerged for up to 30 days at a time. This device though would later be used in satellites to help them navigate space.

nodeAttributes.Photograph: photo on distributed museum website from book Men and Ideas in Engineering

vTarget.nodeDescription: Dr. Robert Wilhemson was the first to create a digital animation of a thunderstorm (it was even nominated for an Academy Award in 1989 and won 14 other awards). He later developed an animation of a tornado forming from a thunderstorm. These technological advancements led to a new process to help with storm predictions. Computer models are now widely used to help understand storm movements.

vSource.nodeDescription: The Earth's critical zone is it's "living skin" that, when studied, looks at how different processes on Earth interact. Praveen Kumar does research on hydrology and its different processes. The critical zone helps us understand how interactions between water, air, life, and rock can be affected by human behavior. More specifically, the critical zone looks at how changing the Earth's surface can affect subsurface processes including waterflow and elements. Kumar's research into water is a key aspect of looking at the critical zone and it's link to climate change.

vTarget.nodeDescription:
"Tami Bond's research focuses on different properties of carbon-containing particles, which can contribute to carbon emissions. This research places an emphasis on the chemistry related to climate change and how climate change, while caused by long-lasting pollutants, is also caused by pollutants that show their effects within a few days. One of Bond's specific focuses are the emissions starting from the industrial revolution, showing a long-term study of pollution and its relationship to climate change.
"

vTarget.nodeLabel: Religious Figures talking about climate change: StewardshipNode name
vTarget.nodeDescription: Psychology graduate student Faith Shin conducted research on how different messages within Christianity were linked to how people viewed and responded to climate change. Shin found that messages linked to stewardship (God commands humans to take care of the Earth) often resulted in Christians viewing climate change concern as a moral imperative. This is compared to dominion beliefs, which advocate for the idea that God gives humans free reign. Dominion beliefs are linked tot lower concerncocnern for climate change. Shin conducted this research through having different groups read different articles including: Bible passages (either stewardship or dominion) or a control article. An interesting find is that while the stewardship articles showed an increase inmore moral concern about climate change, the dominion articles did not reduce moral concerns.

vSource.nodeLabel: William Fry and an ultrasound for non-invasive surgeries
vSource.nodeDescription: William Fry, a professor in the eletrical engineering apartment, pioneered the ultrasound for use in non-invasive surgeries. He built his ultrasound equipment specifically to study how ultrasounds would effect animal tissue. His research led to its use on woman with late stage breast cancer, trying it out on five different woman. What makes this interesting is that one of the women lived twenty month longer after doing the ultrasound procedure. Along with his study on late stage breast cancer, he used the ultrasound technology to study the nervous system. A man of many talents, he also worked with his brother to create an artificial heart, keeping a dog alive for nine hours with the artificial heart!

vTarget.nodeDescription:
i. Measuring a star’s brightness would take hours of observation and calculations. Astronomy professor Joel Stebbins in collaboration with physics professors F.C. Brown and Jakob Kunz would develop the photoelectric photometer which would use electricity to help simplify this process. 
 
 ii. Stebbins credited his wife as the driving force for this idea. When they were first married she would sometimes go to the observatory with him to help him get his work done faster so they could spend more time together. He told her one day they would be able to do this much faster with electricity and from then on she encouraged him to discover this method. A couple of months later he went to a physics open house where F.C. Brown had a demonstration of a selenium cell. Stebbins worked with Brown to create a selenium cell photometer.
 
 iii. While the selenium cell photometer helped discover five new eclipsing binary stars, Stebbins felt it was not strong enough. He was introduced to Jakob Kunz, who had been working to improve photoelectric cells. They collaborated to create and continually refine the photoelectric photometer. This development allowed for stebbins to better research variable stars and he was able to measure diameters and masses more accurately than any other instrument had been able to provide up to that point.

vTarget.nodeDescription: As greenhouse gases and carbon dioxide continue to increase in our atmosphere, there has been much research done on what the possible impacts will be to our food supply. A multidisciplinary team at the University of Illinois was the first to conduct outdoor research on the effects of increased carbon dioxide on crops in a project called the Soybean Free Air Concentration Enrichment (SoyFACE). Previous studies have grown crops inside greenhouses to study what the changes in atmosphere may entail. For SoyFACE, Llarge octagonal plots are established with the ability to release higher concentrations of carbon dioxide and ozone on any side of the plot. This helps account for wind carrying the gases across the plot. This innovative way allows for crops to be grown with typical conditions but with future atmospheric conditions.

nodeAttributes.College: ACES/ LAS/ School of Integrative biology/ Institute for Genomic Biology

vTarget.nodeDescription: Professor Emma Mercier and her research team created a new app called "Food for Thought" which tells children about the carbon footprint created by the food they eat. The app tells the nutritional data along with the carbon footprint. Mercier's goal is twofold: to help children be more "data literate" and learn more about the causes of climate change. To do this research, Mercier and her team videotaped children learning about climate change and their food carbon footprint. The focus on food was to look at what children have more control over, which makes climate change awareness and learning more accessible.

nodeAttributes.Observations: link to University Laboratory High School

vSource.nodeLabel: Using Fitness Trackers in research to monitor health
vSource.nodeDescription: Dr. Ruby Mendenhall is a jack of all trades, conducting research in various disciplines, all of which focus on black women and poverty and inequality. One of her focuses is on how stress based on gun violence would affect the genomes of black woman. Mendenhall and her team took blood samples to help create a fitness tracker. She worked with other departments, including the NCSA to help track black women's lives and history. In this case, Mendenhall is looking at "health" with regards to historical and cultural issues, calling on a wide range of experts to help her with her research.

vSource.nodeDescription: Professor Thomas Cureton created the Physical Fitness Research lab in Huff Hall (now the home of the School of Applied Health Sciences), running this research facility from 1944 to 1969. This research facility focused on increasing scientific understanding of the work productivity of the human body (achieved through fitness tests), developing standards for those fitness tests, diagnosing physical conditions based on fitness test results, and creating conditioning exercises. Beyond those initial goals, the lab also researched the effects of exercise with regards to health as well as studying what makes athletes successful. Some major tests that Cureton had a hand in included: Cureton Muscular Endurance Test, the Cureton test of Swimming Endurance, the Illinois 14-item motor fitness test, the Cureton All-Out Treadmill Run test, the Cureton-Illinois Motor Fitness Test, and the Cureton Flexibility Test.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Tony Wong Large Magellanic Cloud to look at star formation
vTarget.nodeDescription: Astronomy professor Tony Wong and a group of researchers were able to map how stars are born in the nearest star-forming galaxy. Wong and his team hope to use this information to understand our own galaxy. Wong used the Large Magellanic Cloud (nearby galaxy) to study, as it it tilted face-on. This tilt makes it easier for astronomers to study star formation. Based on what they are able to see, they decided to focus on molecular clouds as a base for star formation. They used a telescope in Australia to look at the Large Magellanic Cloud straight on to view those molecular clouds.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Religious Figures talking about climate change: StewardshipNode name
vTarget.nodeDescription: Psychology graduate student Faith Shin conducted research on how different messages within Christianity were linked to how people viewed and responded to climate change. Shin found that messages linked to stewardship (God commands humans to take care of the Earth) often resulted in Christians viewing climate change concern as a moral imperative. This is compared to dominion beliefs, which advocate for the idea that God gives humans free reign. Dominion beliefs are linked tot lower concerncocnern for climate change. Shin conducted this research through having different groups read different articles including: Bible passages (either stewardship or dominion) or a control article. An interesting find is that while the stewardship articles showed an increase inmore moral concern about climate change, the dominion articles did not reduce moral concerns.

vSource.nodeDescription: Professor Thomas Cureton created the Physical Fitness Research lab in Huff Hall (now the home of the School of Applied Health Sciences), running this research facility from 1944 to 1969. This research facility focused on increasing scientific understanding of the work productivity of the human body (achieved through fitness tests), developing standards for those fitness tests, diagnosing physical conditions based on fitness test results, and creating conditioning exercises. Beyond those initial goals, the lab also researched the effects of exercise with regards to health as well as studying what makes athletes successful. Some major tests that Cureton had a hand in included: Cureton Muscular Endurance Test, the Cureton test of Swimming Endurance, the Illinois 14-item motor fitness test, the Cureton All-Out Treadmill Run test, the Cureton-Illinois Motor Fitness Test, and the Cureton Flexibility Test.

vTarget.nodeDescription: The Earth's critical zone is it's "living skin" that, when studied, looks at how different processes on Earth interact. Praveen Kumar does research on hydrology and its different processes. The critical zone helps us understand how interactions between water, air, life, and rock can be affected by human behavior. More specifically, the critical zone looks at how changing the Earth's surface can affect subsurface processes including waterflow and elements. Kumar's research into water is a key aspect of looking at the critical zone and it's link to climate change.

vSource.nodeLabel: Node nameThreonine and William C. Rose
vSource.nodeDescription: Rose discovered the amino acid Threonine and that amino acids are required in our diets after studying amino acids in rats' diets. Rose found in the 1930s that rats, when fed a variety of amino acids, would die until they ingested "casein" in milk. Rose, figuring that casein included an essential amino acid to life, eventually discovered threonine. After this initial research, Rose moved on to human diets, feeding male graduate students with the essential amino acids. This research was awared the National Medal of Science in biological sciences in 1966. So, we ought to thank William C. Rose for helping us know what food is best for us!

vTarget.nodeDescription: The University of Illinois has been studying the relationship between nature and humans since its earliest days. From 1884 to 1921, Stephen Forbes was a professor in zoology and entomology who mostly studied insects, birds, fish and crustaceans. His major area of focus was the interactions between species and how these interactions affected the agricultural industry. His publications were some of the earliest work in what is now known as the field of ecology and he is considered as one of the founders of the formal field. Looking at how animals and humans have an impact on each other’s environments, habits, and culture is also an important part of climate change research currently taking place.

nodeAttributes.Department: Illinois Natural History Survey/ zoology/ entomology

vTarget.nodeLabel: Global Warming effects on the Houma Tribe (Shanondora Billiot’s research)
vTarget.nodeDescription: Shanondora BIllet went to Louisiana's Gulf Coast to interview members from the United Houma Nation to look at how the destruction of the coast has affected their lives and worldview. After being vetted by leaders of the tribe, BIllet was able to see that the tribe, which makes its living via the water (fishing, shrimping, trapping, etc.) and had to change how they made their living. With the new changes to the coast and to the water, older members of the Houma tribe find it difficult to pass on their traditions to youngermembers, causing distress. This climate change and destruction of the coast has caused a nation to reevaluate their way of life and their traditions.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Peter Nardulli's study on climate change and the possible link to civil unrest
vTarget.nodeDescription: Peter Nardulli with Buddy Peyton and Joseph Bajjalieh, used SPEED (a big data resource) to conducted research on climate change and civil unrest after weather-related climate change catastrophes. They found that areas where there waswho use violence prior to a climate change event were more likely to have increased violence after a natural disaster. The goal ofy wanted to focus on this research was to help fix policies surrounding civil unrest, and help leaders helping areas know how long unrest can last after a climate change event. To figure out this research, Nardulli and his team used a random sample of storms and floods and examined looked at data surrounding civil unrest in the affected areas to complete this research in certain cities affected by the climate change events.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Deke Weaver's art on tigers and effect of climate change
vTarget.nodeDescription: Deke Weaver, professor of new media, created and starred in a show called TIGER from a five-part series called "The Unreliable Bestiary." In this show and this series, Weaver talks about famous tigers, such as Tony the Tiger and the tigers from the Jungle Book, as well as how humans interact with tigers. This was created to call attention to climate change and how it affects wildlife. To further comment on this, Weaver performed the show along the Mississippi River and its watershed to comment on migration as a result of climate change.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Professor Emma Mercier and her research team created a new app called "Food for Thought" which tells children about the carbon footprint created by the food they eat. The app tells the nutritional data along with the carbon footprint. Mercier's goal is twofold: to help children be more "data literate" and learn more about the causes of climate change. To do this research, Mercier and her team videotaped children learning about climate change and their food carbon footprint. The focus on food was to look at what children have more control over, which makes climate change awareness and learning more accessible.

vTarget.nodeLabel: "Other Natures" book about Ancient Greek ethnographies
vTarget.nodeDescription: Professor Clara Bosak-Schroder looks at ethnographies written by Herodotus and Diodorus to see how their works look in the context of current climate change issues. These ethnographies (ancient travelogues) look at differences in consumption, something that is more relevant now as we look to different things to eat in the wake of a changing climate. Bosak-Schroder thinks that these ethnographies can help current leaders find ways to view and fix climate change issues. She also focuses on how people are educated about climate issues, which is another way that these ancient words can help influence modern thinking.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Node descriptionSometimes an innovation can be used for multiple purposes, some not even imagined while creating it. The electrostatic gyroscope was created at the University of Illinois by Howard Knoebel. The electrostatic gyroscope was initially invented to be used in submarines - which needed an instrument that would not need to be calibrated since it would be submerged for up to 30 days at a time. This device though would later be used in satellites to help them navigate space.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Dr. Robert Wilhemson was the first to create a digital animation of a thunderstorm (it was even nominated for an Academy Award in 1989 and won 14 other awards). He later developed an animation of a tornado forming from a thunderstorm. These technological advancements led to a new process to help with storm predictions. Computer models are now widely used to help understand storm movements.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Tracking Sputnik I's Orbit with minitrack inferometer
vTarget.nodeDescription: George Swenson obtained the minitrack inferometer for members of the Illinois Astronomical Society to track Sputnik I's orbit on October 4, 1957. On the night in question, the inferometer was able to get measurements of Sputnik and were able to use Doppler Radar data. Members of the department used the data from the Doppler and inferometer to study its orbit. This data helped advance sateillite-based astronomical research and was helped with grants from the National Research Council, NASA, and the Air Force.

vSource.nodeDescription: Dr. Timothy Nugent, a professor Rehabilitation Education, pioneered the National Wheelchair Basketball Association in 1949. He created this league to help destigmatize those with disabilities, aiming to change the societal and cultural views towards disability. This idea initially began after World War II, where Nugent found it necessary to create programs for wounded veterans. Nugent's league eventually included both men's and women's teams that played in the Olympics in 1968, and can still be seen playing here at the University, maintaining Nugent's original view of a destigmatized sport.

nodeAttributes.Current Faculty research: Men's Wheelchair Basketball Coach: Matt Buchi  , Women's Wheelchair Basketball Coach: Stephanie Wheeler

vTarget.nodeDescription: The University of Illinois has been studying the relationship between nature and humans since its earliest days. From 1884 to 1921, Stephen Forbes was a professor in zoology and entomology who mostly studied insects, birds, fish and crustaceans. His major area of focus was the interactions between species and how these interactions affected the agricultural industry. His publications were some of the earliest work in what is now known as the field of ecology and he is considered as one of the founders of the formal field. Looking at how animals and humans have an impact on each other’s environments, habits, and culture is also an important part of climate change research currently taking place.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Global Warming effects on the Houma Tribe (Shanondora Billiot’s research)
vTarget.nodeDescription: Shanondora BIllet went to Louisiana's Gulf Coast to interview members from the United Houma Nation to look at how the destruction of the coast has affected their lives and worldview. After being vetted by leaders of the tribe, BIllet was able to see that the tribe, which makes its living via the water (fishing, shrimping, trapping, etc.) and had to change how they made their living. With the new changes to the coast and to the water, older members of the Houma tribe find it difficult to pass on their traditions to youngermembers, causing distress. This climate change and destruction of the coast has caused a nation to reevaluate their way of life and their traditions.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Religious Figures talking about climate change: StewardshipNode name
vTarget.nodeDescription: Psychology graduate student Faith Shin conducted research on how different messages within Christianity were linked to how people viewed and responded to climate change. Shin found that messages linked to stewardship (God commands humans to take care of the Earth) often resulted in Christians viewing climate change concern as a moral imperative. This is compared to dominion beliefs, which advocate for the idea that God gives humans free reign. Dominion beliefs are linked tot lower concerncocnern for climate change. Shin conducted this research through having different groups read different articles including: Bible passages (either stewardship or dominion) or a control article. An interesting find is that while the stewardship articles showed an increase inmore moral concern about climate change, the dominion articles did not reduce moral concerns.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Peter Nardulli's study on climate change and the possible link to civil unrest
vTarget.nodeDescription: Peter Nardulli with Buddy Peyton and Joseph Bajjalieh, used SPEED (a big data resource) to conducted research on climate change and civil unrest after weather-related climate change catastrophes. They found that areas where there waswho use violence prior to a climate change event were more likely to have increased violence after a natural disaster. The goal ofy wanted to focus on this research was to help fix policies surrounding civil unrest, and help leaders helping areas know how long unrest can last after a climate change event. To figure out this research, Nardulli and his team used a random sample of storms and floods and examined looked at data surrounding civil unrest in the affected areas to complete this research in certain cities affected by the climate change events.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Deke Weaver's art on tigers and effect of climate change
vTarget.nodeDescription: Deke Weaver, professor of new media, created and starred in a show called TIGER from a five-part series called "The Unreliable Bestiary." In this show and this series, Weaver talks about famous tigers, such as Tony the Tiger and the tigers from the Jungle Book, as well as how humans interact with tigers. This was created to call attention to climate change and how it affects wildlife. To further comment on this, Weaver performed the show along the Mississippi River and its watershed to comment on migration as a result of climate change.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Professor Emma Mercier and her research team created a new app called "Food for Thought" which tells children about the carbon footprint created by the food they eat. The app tells the nutritional data along with the carbon footprint. Mercier's goal is twofold: to help children be more "data literate" and learn more about the causes of climate change. To do this research, Mercier and her team videotaped children learning about climate change and their food carbon footprint. The focus on food was to look at what children have more control over, which makes climate change awareness and learning more accessible.

vTarget.nodeLabel: "Other Natures" book about Ancient Greek ethnographies
vTarget.nodeDescription: Professor Clara Bosak-Schroder looks at ethnographies written by Herodotus and Diodorus to see how their works look in the context of current climate change issues. These ethnographies (ancient travelogues) look at differences in consumption, something that is more relevant now as we look to different things to eat in the wake of a changing climate. Bosak-Schroder thinks that these ethnographies can help current leaders find ways to view and fix climate change issues. She also focuses on how people are educated about climate issues, which is another way that these ancient words can help influence modern thinking.

vTarget.nodeDescription: The Earth's critical zone is it's "living skin" that, when studied, looks at how different processes on Earth interact. Praveen Kumar does research on hydrology and its different processes. The critical zone helps us understand how interactions between water, air, life, and rock can be affected by human behavior. More specifically, the critical zone looks at how changing the Earth's surface can affect subsurface processes including waterflow and elements. Kumar's research into water is a key aspect of looking at the critical zone and it's link to climate change.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Node nameThreonine and William C. Rose
vTarget.nodeDescription: Rose discovered the amino acid Threonine and that amino acids are required in our diets after studying amino acids in rats' diets. Rose found in the 1930s that rats, when fed a variety of amino acids, would die until they ingested "casein" in milk. Rose, figuring that casein included an essential amino acid to life, eventually discovered threonine. After this initial research, Rose moved on to human diets, feeding male graduate students with the essential amino acids. This research was awared the National Medal of Science in biological sciences in 1966. So, we ought to thank William C. Rose for helping us know what food is best for us!

nodeAttributes.Observations: Have to find this research from Illinois publications
nodeAttributes.Current Faculty research: Hans H. Stein has done a version of this research with regards to pig diets (Animal Sciences)

vSource.nodeDescription: PAC-1 is an anti-cancer drug discovered by Professor Paul Hergenrother and further developed with the help from Professor Timothy Fan. PAC-! is an abbreviation for procaspase-activating compound and was discovered in Hergenrother's lab when he was studying 20,000 compounds  to see their ability to turn on an enzyme that can selectively kill cancer cells. Along with Hergenrother and Fan, one of the main researchers was a daschund with a brain tumor named Pretzel, who acted as one of the test dogs, with success. Pretzel, after going through treatment with PAC-1 and standard cancer treatment, had her tumor shrinked and her life expectancy extended.

nodeAttributes.Photograph: Picture with Hoover, a research dog (link)

vTarget.nodeDescription: Node descriptionSometimes an innovation can be used for multiple purposes, some not even imagined while creating it. The electrostatic gyroscope was created at the University of Illinois by Howard Knoebel. The electrostatic gyroscope was initially invented to be used in submarines - which needed an instrument that would not need to be calibrated since it would be submerged for up to 30 days at a time. This device though would later be used in satellites to help them navigate space.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Dr. Robert Wilhemson was the first to create a digital animation of a thunderstorm (it was even nominated for an Academy Award in 1989 and won 14 other awards). He later developed an animation of a tornado forming from a thunderstorm. These technological advancements led to a new process to help with storm predictions. Computer models are now widely used to help understand storm movements.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Tony Wong Large Magellanic Cloud to look at star formation
vTarget.nodeDescription: Astronomy professor Tony Wong and a group of researchers were able to map how stars are born in the nearest star-forming galaxy. Wong and his team hope to use this information to understand our own galaxy. Wong used the Large Magellanic Cloud (nearby galaxy) to study, as it it tilted face-on. This tilt makes it easier for astronomers to study star formation. Based on what they are able to see, they decided to focus on molecular clouds as a base for star formation. They used a telescope in Australia to look at the Large Magellanic Cloud straight on to view those molecular clouds.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Tracking Sputnik I's Orbit with minitrack inferometer
vTarget.nodeDescription: George Swenson obtained the minitrack inferometer for members of the Illinois Astronomical Society to track Sputnik I's orbit on October 4, 1957. On the night in question, the inferometer was able to get measurements of Sputnik and were able to use Doppler Radar data. Members of the department used the data from the Doppler and inferometer to study its orbit. This data helped advance sateillite-based astronomical research and was helped with grants from the National Research Council, NASA, and the Air Force.

nodeAttributes.Current Faculty research: George Swenson, George McVitte, Stanley Wyatt, Ivan King

vTarget.nodeDescription: Professor Thomas Cureton created the Physical Fitness Research lab in Huff Hall (now the home of the School of Applied Health Sciences), running this research facility from 1944 to 1969. This research facility focused on increasing scientific understanding of the work productivity of the human body (achieved through fitness tests), developing standards for those fitness tests, diagnosing physical conditions based on fitness test results, and creating conditioning exercises. Beyond those initial goals, the lab also researched the effects of exercise with regards to health as well as studying what makes athletes successful. Some major tests that Cureton had a hand in included: Cureton Muscular Endurance Test, the Cureton test of Swimming Endurance, the Illinois 14-item motor fitness test, the Cureton All-Out Treadmill Run test, the Cureton-Illinois Motor Fitness Test, and the Cureton Flexibility Test.

vSource.nodeDescription: Isabelle Bevier started the Home Economics program with an emphasis on scientific research and health. In 1900, Bevier created the Home Economics Program essentially from scratch, having no precedent to look to. With this freedom, she created a program that focused on the health aspects of home economics and nutrition. Part of that research helped Bevier figure out the idea to use a thermometer to promote safe cooking of meat, applying key aspects of chemistry to promote food safety. To do this, she worked in tandem with the Department of Animal Husbandry.

nodeAttributes.Observations: Lots of stuff in archives...worth a look; here's another link: https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/84903192.pdf

vTarget.nodeLabel: Global Warming effects on the Houma Tribe (Shanondora Billiot’s research)
vTarget.nodeDescription: Shanondora BIllet went to Louisiana's Gulf Coast to interview members from the United Houma Nation to look at how the destruction of the coast has affected their lives and worldview. After being vetted by leaders of the tribe, BIllet was able to see that the tribe, which makes its living via the water (fishing, shrimping, trapping, etc.) and had to change how they made their living. With the new changes to the coast and to the water, older members of the Houma tribe find it difficult to pass on their traditions to youngermembers, causing distress. This climate change and destruction of the coast has caused a nation to reevaluate their way of life and their traditions.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Religious Figures talking about climate change: StewardshipNode name
vTarget.nodeDescription: Psychology graduate student Faith Shin conducted research on how different messages within Christianity were linked to how people viewed and responded to climate change. Shin found that messages linked to stewardship (God commands humans to take care of the Earth) often resulted in Christians viewing climate change concern as a moral imperative. This is compared to dominion beliefs, which advocate for the idea that God gives humans free reign. Dominion beliefs are linked tot lower concerncocnern for climate change. Shin conducted this research through having different groups read different articles including: Bible passages (either stewardship or dominion) or a control article. An interesting find is that while the stewardship articles showed an increase inmore moral concern about climate change, the dominion articles did not reduce moral concerns.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Peter Nardulli's study on climate change and the possible link to civil unrest
vTarget.nodeDescription: Peter Nardulli with Buddy Peyton and Joseph Bajjalieh, used SPEED (a big data resource) to conducted research on climate change and civil unrest after weather-related climate change catastrophes. They found that areas where there waswho use violence prior to a climate change event were more likely to have increased violence after a natural disaster. The goal ofy wanted to focus on this research was to help fix policies surrounding civil unrest, and help leaders helping areas know how long unrest can last after a climate change event. To figure out this research, Nardulli and his team used a random sample of storms and floods and examined looked at data surrounding civil unrest in the affected areas to complete this research in certain cities affected by the climate change events.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Deke Weaver's art on tigers and effect of climate change
vTarget.nodeDescription: Deke Weaver, professor of new media, created and starred in a show called TIGER from a five-part series called "The Unreliable Bestiary." In this show and this series, Weaver talks about famous tigers, such as Tony the Tiger and the tigers from the Jungle Book, as well as how humans interact with tigers. This was created to call attention to climate change and how it affects wildlife. To further comment on this, Weaver performed the show along the Mississippi River and its watershed to comment on migration as a result of climate change.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Professor Emma Mercier and her research team created a new app called "Food for Thought" which tells children about the carbon footprint created by the food they eat. The app tells the nutritional data along with the carbon footprint. Mercier's goal is twofold: to help children be more "data literate" and learn more about the causes of climate change. To do this research, Mercier and her team videotaped children learning about climate change and their food carbon footprint. The focus on food was to look at what children have more control over, which makes climate change awareness and learning more accessible.

vTarget.nodeLabel: "Other Natures" book about Ancient Greek ethnographies
vTarget.nodeDescription: Professor Clara Bosak-Schroder looks at ethnographies written by Herodotus and Diodorus to see how their works look in the context of current climate change issues. These ethnographies (ancient travelogues) look at differences in consumption, something that is more relevant now as we look to different things to eat in the wake of a changing climate. Bosak-Schroder thinks that these ethnographies can help current leaders find ways to view and fix climate change issues. She also focuses on how people are educated about climate issues, which is another way that these ancient words can help influence modern thinking.

vTarget.nodeDescription: The Earth's critical zone is it's "living skin" that, when studied, looks at how different processes on Earth interact. Praveen Kumar does research on hydrology and its different processes. The critical zone helps us understand how interactions between water, air, life, and rock can be affected by human behavior. More specifically, the critical zone looks at how changing the Earth's surface can affect subsurface processes including waterflow and elements. Kumar's research into water is a key aspect of looking at the critical zone and it's link to climate change.
