vTarget.nodeLabel: Node nameThreonine and William C. Rose
vTarget.nodeDescription: Rose discovered the amino acid Threonine and that amino acids are required in our diets after studying amino acids in rats' diets. Rose found in the 1930s that rats, when fed a variety of amino acids, would die until they ingested "casein" in milk. Rose, figuring that casein included an essential amino acid to life, eventually discovered threonine. After this initial research, Rose moved on to human diets, feeding male graduate students with the essential amino acids. This research was awared the National Medal of Science in biological sciences in 1966. So, we ought to thank William C. Rose for helping us know what food is best for us!

vTarget.nodeDescription: Dr. Timothy Nugent, a professor Rehabilitation Education, pioneered the National Wheelchair Basketball Association in 1949. He created this league to help destigmatize those with disabilities, aiming to change the societal and cultural views towards disability. This idea initially began after World War II, where Nugent found it necessary to create programs for wounded veterans. Nugent's league eventually included both men's and women's teams that played in the Olympics in 1968, and can still be seen playing here at the University, maintaining Nugent's original view of a destigmatized sport.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Node descriptionSometimes an innovation can be used for multiple purposes, some not even imagined while creating it. The electrostatic gyroscope was created at the University of Illinois by Howard Knoebel. The electrostatic gyroscope was initially invented to be used in submarines - which needed an instrument that would not need to be calibrated since it would be submerged for up to 30 days at a time. This device though would later be used in satellites to help them navigate space.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Dr. Robert Wilhemson was the first to create a digital animation of a thunderstorm (it was even nominated for an Academy Award in 1989 and won 14 other awards). He later developed an animation of a tornado forming from a thunderstorm. These technological advancements led to a new process to help with storm predictions. Computer models are now widely used to help understand storm movements.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Tony Wong Large Magellanic Cloud to look at star formation
vTarget.nodeDescription: Astronomy professor Tony Wong and a group of researchers were able to map how stars are born in the nearest star-forming galaxy. Wong and his team hope to use this information to understand our own galaxy. Wong used the Large Magellanic Cloud (nearby galaxy) to study, as it it tilted face-on. This tilt makes it easier for astronomers to study star formation. Based on what they are able to see, they decided to focus on molecular clouds as a base for star formation. They used a telescope in Australia to look at the Large Magellanic Cloud straight on to view those molecular clouds.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Tracking Sputnik I's Orbit with minitrack inferometer
vTarget.nodeDescription: George Swenson obtained the minitrack inferometer for members of the Illinois Astronomical Society to track Sputnik I's orbit on October 4, 1957. On the night in question, the inferometer was able to get measurements of Sputnik and were able to use Doppler Radar data. Members of the department used the data from the Doppler and inferometer to study its orbit. This data helped advance sateillite-based astronomical research and was helped with grants from the National Research Council, NASA, and the Air Force.

nodeAttributes.Current Faculty research: George Swenson, George McVitte, Stanley Wyatt, Ivan King

vTarget.nodeDescription:
"Tami Bond's research focuses on different properties of carbon-containing particles, which can contribute to carbon emissions. This research places an emphasis on the chemistry related to climate change and how climate change, while caused by long-lasting pollutants, is also caused by pollutants that show their effects within a few days. One of Bond's specific focuses are the emissions starting from the industrial revolution, showing a long-term study of pollution and its relationship to climate change.
"

vTarget.nodeDescription: Professor Thomas Cureton created the Physical Fitness Research lab in Huff Hall (now the home of the School of Applied Health Sciences), running this research facility from 1944 to 1969. This research facility focused on increasing scientific understanding of the work productivity of the human body (achieved through fitness tests), developing standards for those fitness tests, diagnosing physical conditions based on fitness test results, and creating conditioning exercises. Beyond those initial goals, the lab also researched the effects of exercise with regards to health as well as studying what makes athletes successful. Some major tests that Cureton had a hand in included: Cureton Muscular Endurance Test, the Cureton test of Swimming Endurance, the Illinois 14-item motor fitness test, the Cureton All-Out Treadmill Run test, the Cureton-Illinois Motor Fitness Test, and the Cureton Flexibility Test.

vTarget.nodeDescription: PAC-1 is an anti-cancer drug discovered by Professor Paul Hergenrother and further developed with the help from Professor Timothy Fan. PAC-! is an abbreviation for procaspase-activating compound and was discovered in Hergenrother's lab when he was studying 20,000 compounds  to see their ability to turn on an enzyme that can selectively kill cancer cells. Along with Hergenrother and Fan, one of the main researchers was a daschund with a brain tumor named Pretzel, who acted as one of the test dogs, with success. Pretzel, after going through treatment with PAC-1 and standard cancer treatment, had her tumor shrinked and her life expectancy extended.

nodeAttributes.Photograph: Picture with Hoover, a research dog (link)

vSource.nodeDescription: Karen Dina Tabb created the IDEA coalition in 2017  to improve maternal mental health awareness by identifying risk factors during the perinatal period. In 2018, Tabb and her team obtained funding from the Patient-Centered Outcomes Research Institute (PCORI) to create an advisory board to engage local people. The IDEA coalition quickly gained ground, hosting a national symposium in 2019, a mental-health film screening in both 2018 and 2019, and many other meetings. By this past spring (2020), the coalition received four funding awards to maintain their research, which they do along with students, faculty, and patients. The IDEA Coalition expanded to rural areas to help every population with perinatal depression.

vTarget.nodeDescription: George Swenson obtained the minitrack inferometer for members of the Illinois Astronomical Society to track Sputnik I's orbit on October 4, 1957. On the night in question, the inferometer was able to get measurements of Sputnik and were able to use Doppler Radar data. Members of the department used the data from the Doppler and inferometer to study its orbit. This data helped advance sateillite-based astronomical research and was helped with grants from the National Research Council, NASA, and the Air Force.

nodeAttributes.Current Faculty research: George Swenson, George McVitte, Stanley Wyatt, Ivan King

vSource.nodeDescription: Karen Dina Tabb created the IDEA coalition in 2017  to improve maternal mental health awareness by identifying risk factors during the perinatal period. In 2018, Tabb and her team obtained funding from the Patient-Centered Outcomes Research Institute (PCORI) to create an advisory board to engage local people. The IDEA coalition quickly gained ground, hosting a national symposium in 2019, a mental-health film screening in both 2018 and 2019, and many other meetings. By this past spring (2020), the coalition received four funding awards to maintain their research, which they do along with students, faculty, and patients. The IDEA Coalition expanded to rural areas to help every population with perinatal depression.

vTarget.nodeDescription:
"Tami Bond's research focuses on different properties of carbon-containing particles, which can contribute to carbon emissions. This research places an emphasis on the chemistry related to climate change and how climate change, while caused by long-lasting pollutants, is also caused by pollutants that show their effects within a few days. One of Bond's specific focuses are the emissions starting from the industrial revolution, showing a long-term study of pollution and its relationship to climate change.
"

vTarget.nodeLabel: Religious Figures talking about climate change: StewardshipNode name
vTarget.nodeDescription: Psychology graduate student Faith Shin conducted research on how different messages within Christianity were linked to how people viewed and responded to climate change. Shin found that messages linked to stewardship (God commands humans to take care of the Earth) often resulted in Christians viewing climate change concern as a moral imperative. This is compared to dominion beliefs, which advocate for the idea that God gives humans free reign. Dominion beliefs are linked tot lower concerncocnern for climate change. Shin conducted this research through having different groups read different articles including: Bible passages (either stewardship or dominion) or a control article. An interesting find is that while the stewardship articles showed an increase inmore moral concern about climate change, the dominion articles did not reduce moral concerns.

vTarget.nodeDescription: The Earth's critical zone is it's "living skin" that, when studied, looks at how different processes on Earth interact. Praveen Kumar does research on hydrology and its different processes. The critical zone helps us understand how interactions between water, air, life, and rock can be affected by human behavior. More specifically, the critical zone looks at how changing the Earth's surface can affect subsurface processes including waterflow and elements. Kumar's research into water is a key aspect of looking at the critical zone and it's link to climate change.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Professor Thomas Cureton created the Physical Fitness Research lab in Huff Hall (now the home of the School of Applied Health Sciences), running this research facility from 1944 to 1969. This research facility focused on increasing scientific understanding of the work productivity of the human body (achieved through fitness tests), developing standards for those fitness tests, diagnosing physical conditions based on fitness test results, and creating conditioning exercises. Beyond those initial goals, the lab also researched the effects of exercise with regards to health as well as studying what makes athletes successful. Some major tests that Cureton had a hand in included: Cureton Muscular Endurance Test, the Cureton test of Swimming Endurance, the Illinois 14-item motor fitness test, the Cureton All-Out Treadmill Run test, the Cureton-Illinois Motor Fitness Test, and the Cureton Flexibility Test.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Node nameThreonine and William C. Rose
vTarget.nodeDescription: Rose discovered the amino acid Threonine and that amino acids are required in our diets after studying amino acids in rats' diets. Rose found in the 1930s that rats, when fed a variety of amino acids, would die until they ingested "casein" in milk. Rose, figuring that casein included an essential amino acid to life, eventually discovered threonine. After this initial research, Rose moved on to human diets, feeding male graduate students with the essential amino acids. This research was awared the National Medal of Science in biological sciences in 1966. So, we ought to thank William C. Rose for helping us know what food is best for us!

vTarget.nodeDescription: PAC-1 is an anti-cancer drug discovered by Professor Paul Hergenrother and further developed with the help from Professor Timothy Fan. PAC-! is an abbreviation for procaspase-activating compound and was discovered in Hergenrother's lab when he was studying 20,000 compounds  to see their ability to turn on an enzyme that can selectively kill cancer cells. Along with Hergenrother and Fan, one of the main researchers was a daschund with a brain tumor named Pretzel, who acted as one of the test dogs, with success. Pretzel, after going through treatment with PAC-1 and standard cancer treatment, had her tumor shrinked and her life expectancy extended.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Isabelle Bevier started the Home Economics program with an emphasis on scientific research and health. In 1900, Bevier created the Home Economics Program essentially from scratch, having no precedent to look to. With this freedom, she created a program that focused on the health aspects of home economics and nutrition. Part of that research helped Bevier figure out the idea to use a thermometer to promote safe cooking of meat, applying key aspects of chemistry to promote food safety. To do this, she worked in tandem with the Department of Animal Husbandry.

nodeAttributes.Observations: Lots of stuff in archives...worth a look; here's another link: https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/84903192.pdf
nodeAttributes.Current Faculty research: Marla Todd: Associate Director of Advancement Communications

vSource.nodeDescription: For the last decade, the Krannert Center has been hosting the Dance for People with Parkinson's, a program that invites those with Parkinson's to come together to dance and move their bodies. This program works to provide those with Parkinson's to embrace their body movements in a judgement free zone, combining health with dance and music. The dancers go at their own pace and utilize the space in ways that their ability can afford them to. Regardless of their range of motion, there is a joyful mood surrounding the class, as it creates a space for people to embrace the music and temporarily step away from Parkinson's and to promote both physical and mental health habits.

nodeAttributes.College: College of Fine and Applied Arts

vTarget.nodeDescription: Node descriptionSometimes an innovation can be used for multiple purposes, some not even imagined while creating it. The electrostatic gyroscope was created at the University of Illinois by Howard Knoebel. The electrostatic gyroscope was initially invented to be used in submarines - which needed an instrument that would not need to be calibrated since it would be submerged for up to 30 days at a time. This device though would later be used in satellites to help them navigate space.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Dr. Robert Wilhemson was the first to create a digital animation of a thunderstorm (it was even nominated for an Academy Award in 1989 and won 14 other awards). He later developed an animation of a tornado forming from a thunderstorm. These technological advancements led to a new process to help with storm predictions. Computer models are now widely used to help understand storm movements.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Tony Wong Large Magellanic Cloud to look at star formation
vTarget.nodeDescription: Astronomy professor Tony Wong and a group of researchers were able to map how stars are born in the nearest star-forming galaxy. Wong and his team hope to use this information to understand our own galaxy. Wong used the Large Magellanic Cloud (nearby galaxy) to study, as it it tilted face-on. This tilt makes it easier for astronomers to study star formation. Based on what they are able to see, they decided to focus on molecular clouds as a base for star formation. They used a telescope in Australia to look at the Large Magellanic Cloud straight on to view those molecular clouds.

vTarget.nodeDescription: The University of Illinois has been studying the relationship between nature and humans since its earliest days. From 1884 to 1921, Stephen Forbes was a professor in zoology and entomology who mostly studied insects, birds, fish and crustaceans. His major area of focus was the interactions between species and how these interactions affected the agricultural industry. His publications were some of the earliest work in what is now known as the field of ecology and he is considered as one of the founders of the formal field. Looking at how animals and humans have an impact on each other’s environments, habits, and culture is also an important part of climate change research currently taking place.

nodeAttributes.Department: Illinois Natural History Survey/ zoology/ entomology

vTarget.nodeLabel: Global Warming effects on the Houma Tribe (Shanondora Billiot’s research)
vTarget.nodeDescription: Shanondora BIllet went to Louisiana's Gulf Coast to interview members from the United Houma Nation to look at how the destruction of the coast has affected their lives and worldview. After being vetted by leaders of the tribe, BIllet was able to see that the tribe, which makes its living via the water (fishing, shrimping, trapping, etc.) and had to change how they made their living. With the new changes to the coast and to the water, older members of the Houma tribe find it difficult to pass on their traditions to youngermembers, causing distress. This climate change and destruction of the coast has caused a nation to reevaluate their way of life and their traditions.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Religious Figures talking about climate change: StewardshipNode name
vTarget.nodeDescription: Psychology graduate student Faith Shin conducted research on how different messages within Christianity were linked to how people viewed and responded to climate change. Shin found that messages linked to stewardship (God commands humans to take care of the Earth) often resulted in Christians viewing climate change concern as a moral imperative. This is compared to dominion beliefs, which advocate for the idea that God gives humans free reign. Dominion beliefs are linked tot lower concerncocnern for climate change. Shin conducted this research through having different groups read different articles including: Bible passages (either stewardship or dominion) or a control article. An interesting find is that while the stewardship articles showed an increase inmore moral concern about climate change, the dominion articles did not reduce moral concerns.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Peter Nardulli's study on climate change and the possible link to civil unrest
vTarget.nodeDescription: Peter Nardulli with Buddy Peyton and Joseph Bajjalieh, used SPEED (a big data resource) to conducted research on climate change and civil unrest after weather-related climate change catastrophes. They found that areas where there waswho use violence prior to a climate change event were more likely to have increased violence after a natural disaster. The goal ofy wanted to focus on this research was to help fix policies surrounding civil unrest, and help leaders helping areas know how long unrest can last after a climate change event. To figure out this research, Nardulli and his team used a random sample of storms and floods and examined looked at data surrounding civil unrest in the affected areas to complete this research in certain cities affected by the climate change events.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Deke Weaver's art on tigers and effect of climate change
vTarget.nodeDescription: Deke Weaver, professor of new media, created and starred in a show called TIGER from a five-part series called "The Unreliable Bestiary." In this show and this series, Weaver talks about famous tigers, such as Tony the Tiger and the tigers from the Jungle Book, as well as how humans interact with tigers. This was created to call attention to climate change and how it affects wildlife. To further comment on this, Weaver performed the show along the Mississippi River and its watershed to comment on migration as a result of climate change.

The focus on food was to look at what children have more control over, which makes climate change awareness and learning more accessible.

vTarget.nodeLabel: "Other Natures" book about Ancient Greek ethnographies
vTarget.nodeDescription: Professor Clara Bosak-Schroder looks at ethnographies written by Herodotus and Diodorus to see how their works look in the context of current climate change issues. These ethnographies (ancient travelogues) look at differences in consumption, something that is more relevant now as we look to different things to eat in the wake of a changing climate. Bosak-Schroder thinks that these ethnographies can help current leaders find ways to view and fix climate change issues. She also focuses on how people are educated about climate issues, which is another way that these ancient words can help influence modern thinking.

vTarget.nodeDescription: The Earth's critical zone is it's "living skin" that, when studied, looks at how different processes on Earth interact. Praveen Kumar does research on hydrology and its different processes. The critical zone helps us understand how interactions between water, air, life, and rock can be affected by human behavior. More specifically, the critical zone looks at how changing the Earth's surface can affect subsurface processes including waterflow and elements. Kumar's research into water is a key aspect of looking at the critical zone and it's link to climate change.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Node nameThreonine and William C. Rose
vTarget.nodeDescription: Rose discovered the amino acid Threonine and that amino acids are required in our diets after studying amino acids in rats' diets. Rose found in the 1930s that rats, when fed a variety of amino acids, would die until they ingested "casein" in milk. Rose, figuring that casein included an essential amino acid to life, eventually discovered threonine. After this initial research, Rose moved on to human diets, feeding male graduate students with the essential amino acids. This research was awared the National Medal of Science in biological sciences in 1966. So, we ought to thank William C. Rose for helping us know what food is best for us!

vTarget.nodeDescription: Dr. Timothy Nugent, a professor Rehabilitation Education, pioneered the National Wheelchair Basketball Association in 1949. He created this league to help destigmatize those with disabilities, aiming to change the societal and cultural views towards disability. This idea initially began after World War II, where Nugent found it necessary to create programs for wounded veterans. Nugent's league eventually included both men's and women's teams that played in the Olympics in 1968, and can still be seen playing here at the University, maintaining Nugent's original view of a destigmatized sport.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Isabelle Bevier started the Home Economics program with an emphasis on scientific research and health. In 1900, Bevier created the Home Economics Program essentially from scratch, having no precedent to look to. With this freedom, she created a program that focused on the health aspects of home economics and nutrition. Part of that research helped Bevier figure out the idea to use a thermometer to promote safe cooking of meat, applying key aspects of chemistry to promote food safety. To do this, she worked in tandem with the Department of Animal Husbandry.

vSource.nodeDescription: The iBioFab Maker lab at the University of Illinois (as part of the Carle College of Medicine) has done research on how to create a device to detect cancer biomarkers. The current process is a needle biopsy to determine the cancer biomarker, a system that the research team is trying to perfect into a device that uses blood instead of the needle biopsy. The team created a new type of microscope to help make the test easy and and more efficient to perform. This was a collaboration between the engineers and the doctors, showing the power of interdisciplinary research.

vTarget.nodeDescription:
i. Measuring a star’s brightness would take hours of observation and calculations. Astronomy professor Joel Stebbins in collaboration with physics professors F.C. Brown and Jakob Kunz would develop the photoelectric photometer which would use electricity to help simplify this process. 
 
 ii. Stebbins credited his wife as the driving force for this idea. When they were first married she would sometimes go to the observatory with him to help him get his work done faster so they could spend more time together. He told her one day they would be able to do this much faster with electricity and from then on she encouraged him to discover this method. A couple of months later he went to a physics open house where F.C. Brown had a demonstration of a selenium cell. Stebbins worked with Brown to create a selenium cell photometer.
 
 iii. While the selenium cell photometer helped discover five new eclipsing binary stars, Stebbins felt it was not strong enough. He was introduced to Jakob Kunz, who had been working to improve photoelectric cells. They collaborated to create and continually refine the photoelectric photometer. This development allowed for stebbins to better research variable stars and he was able to measure diameters and masses more accurately than any other instrument had been able to provide up to that point.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Node descriptionSometimes an innovation can be used for multiple purposes, some not even imagined while creating it. The electrostatic gyroscope was created at the University of Illinois by Howard Knoebel. The electrostatic gyroscope was initially invented to be used in submarines - which needed an instrument that would not need to be calibrated since it would be submerged for up to 30 days at a time. This device though would later be used in satellites to help them navigate space.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Today, the University of Illinois continues its interdisciplinary and collaborative approach to astronomy. One current project is the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope. This project is an international collaboration with the telescope located in Chile and the data being stored in Champaign Urbana. The National Center for Supercomputing Applications will store the 10 years worth of data, collecting about 20 terabytes of image data a night beginning in 2023. The data will be processed into reports as well as alerting researchers in near-real time of new and unexpected astronomical events.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Dr. Robert Wilhemson was the first to create a digital animation of a thunderstorm (it was even nominated for an Academy Award in 1989 and won 14 other awards). He later developed an animation of a tornado forming from a thunderstorm. These technological advancements led to a new process to help with storm predictions. Computer models are now widely used to help understand storm movements.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Tracking Sputnik I's Orbit with minitrack inferometer
vTarget.nodeDescription: George Swenson obtained the minitrack inferometer for members of the Illinois Astronomical Society to track Sputnik I's orbit on October 4, 1957. On the night in question, the inferometer was able to get measurements of Sputnik and were able to use Doppler Radar data. Members of the department used the data from the Doppler and inferometer to study its orbit. This data helped advance sateillite-based astronomical research and was helped with grants from the National Research Council, NASA, and the Air Force.

vTarget.nodeLabel: IMAX "A Beautiful Planet" with help from NCSA
vTarget.nodeDescription: The Ebert Symposium showed the film "A Beautiful Planet," which the NCSA helped create. The filmmakers collaborated with NCSA to create the opening and closing scenes of virtual intergalactic flight. The NCSA was able to create these scenes through scientific research. This film was shown as part of the "Empathy for the Universe: Storytelling and Data Visualization" tribute to Roger Ebert, a UIUC alum. This tribute also included an interview with astronaut Terry Virts and a variety of professors and alumni that discussed science data visualization in film.

vTarget.nodeDescription: As greenhouse gases and carbon dioxide continue to increase in our atmosphere, there has been much research done on what the possible impacts will be to our food supply. A multidisciplinary team at the University of Illinois was the first to conduct outdoor research on the effects of increased carbon dioxide on crops in a project called the Soybean Free Air Concentration Enrichment (SoyFACE). Previous studies have grown crops inside greenhouses to study what the changes in atmosphere may entail. For SoyFACE, Llarge octagonal plots are established with the ability to release higher concentrations of carbon dioxide and ozone on any side of the plot. This helps account for wind carrying the gases across the plot. This innovative way allows for crops to be grown with typical conditions but with future atmospheric conditions.

vTarget.nodeLabel: William Fry and an ultrasound for non-invasive surgeries
vTarget.nodeDescription: William Fry, a professor in the eletrical engineering apartment, pioneered the ultrasound for use in non-invasive surgeries. He built his ultrasound equipment specifically to study how ultrasounds would effect animal tissue. His research led to its use on woman with late stage breast cancer, trying it out on five different woman. What makes this interesting is that one of the women lived twenty month longer after doing the ultrasound procedure. Along with his study on late stage breast cancer, he used the ultrasound technology to study the nervous system. A man of many talents, he also worked with his brother to create an artificial heart, keeping a dog alive for nine hours with the artificial heart!

vTarget.nodeLabel: Using Fitness Trackers in research to monitor health
vTarget.nodeDescription: Dr. Ruby Mendenhall is a jack of all trades, conducting research in various disciplines, all of which focus on black women and poverty and inequality. One of her focuses is on how stress based on gun violence would affect the genomes of black woman. Mendenhall and her team took blood samples to help create a fitness tracker. She worked with other departments, including the NCSA to help track black women's lives and history. In this case, Mendenhall is looking at "health" with regards to historical and cultural issues, calling on a wide range of experts to help her with her research.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Tony Wong Large Magellanic Cloud to look at star formation
vTarget.nodeDescription: Astronomy professor Tony Wong and a group of researchers were able to map how stars are born in the nearest star-forming galaxy. Wong and his team hope to use this information to understand our own galaxy. Wong used the Large Magellanic Cloud (nearby galaxy) to study, as it it tilted face-on. This tilt makes it easier for astronomers to study star formation. Based on what they are able to see, they decided to focus on molecular clouds as a base for star formation. They used a telescope in Australia to look at the Large Magellanic Cloud straight on to view those molecular clouds.

Members of the department used the data from the Doppler and inferometer to study its orbit. This data helped advance sateillite-based astronomical research and was helped with grants from the National Research Council, NASA, and the Air Force.

nodeAttributes.Current Faculty research: George Swenson, George McVitte, Stanley Wyatt, Ivan King

vSource.nodeDescription: The iBioFab Maker lab at the University of Illinois (as part of the Carle College of Medicine) has done research on how to create a device to detect cancer biomarkers. The current process is a needle biopsy to determine the cancer biomarker, a system that the research team is trying to perfect into a device that uses blood instead of the needle biopsy. The team created a new type of microscope to help make the test easy and and more efficient to perform. This was a collaboration between the engineers and the doctors, showing the power of interdisciplinary research.

One of Bond's specific focuses are the emissions starting from the industrial revolution, showing a long-term study of pollution and its relationship to climate change.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Religious Figures talking about climate change: StewardshipNode name
vTarget.nodeDescription: Psychology graduate student Faith Shin conducted research on how different messages within Christianity were linked to how people viewed and responded to climate change. Shin found that messages linked to stewardship (God commands humans to take care of the Earth) often resulted in Christians viewing climate change concern as a moral imperative. This is compared to dominion beliefs, which advocate for the idea that God gives humans free reign. Dominion beliefs are linked tot lower concerncocnern for climate change. Shin conducted this research through having different groups read different articles including: Bible passages (either stewardship or dominion) or a control article. An interesting find is that while the stewardship articles showed an increase inmore moral concern about climate change, the dominion articles did not reduce moral concerns.

vTarget.nodeDescription: The Earth's critical zone is it's "living skin" that, when studied, looks at how different processes on Earth interact. Praveen Kumar does research on hydrology and its different processes. The critical zone helps us understand how interactions between water, air, life, and rock can be affected by human behavior. More specifically, the critical zone looks at how changing the Earth's surface can affect subsurface processes including waterflow and elements. Kumar's research into water is a key aspect of looking at the critical zone and it's link to climate change.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Professor Thomas Cureton created the Physical Fitness Research lab in Huff Hall (now the home of the School of Applied Health Sciences), running this research facility from 1944 to 1969. This research facility focused on increasing scientific understanding of the work productivity of the human body (achieved through fitness tests), developing standards for those fitness tests, diagnosing physical conditions based on fitness test results, and creating conditioning exercises. Beyond those initial goals, the lab also researched the effects of exercise with regards to health as well as studying what makes athletes successful. Some major tests that Cureton had a hand in included: Cureton Muscular Endurance Test, the Cureton test of Swimming Endurance, the Illinois 14-item motor fitness test, the Cureton All-Out Treadmill Run test, the Cureton-Illinois Motor Fitness Test, and the Cureton Flexibility Test.

The team created a new type of microscope to help make the test easy and and more efficient to perform. This was a collaboration between the engineers and the doctors, showing the power of interdisciplinary research.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Node nameThreonine and William C. Rose
vTarget.nodeDescription: Rose discovered the amino acid Threonine and that amino acids are required in our diets after studying amino acids in rats' diets. Rose found in the 1930s that rats, when fed a variety of amino acids, would die until they ingested "casein" in milk. Rose, figuring that casein included an essential amino acid to life, eventually discovered threonine. After this initial research, Rose moved on to human diets, feeding male graduate students with the essential amino acids. This research was awared the National Medal of Science in biological sciences in 1966. So, we ought to thank William C. Rose for helping us know what food is best for us!

vTarget.nodeDescription: PAC-1 is an anti-cancer drug discovered by Professor Paul Hergenrother and further developed with the help from Professor Timothy Fan. PAC-! is an abbreviation for procaspase-activating compound and was discovered in Hergenrother's lab when he was studying 20,000 compounds  to see their ability to turn on an enzyme that can selectively kill cancer cells. Along with Hergenrother and Fan, one of the main researchers was a daschund with a brain tumor named Pretzel, who acted as one of the test dogs, with success. Pretzel, after going through treatment with PAC-1 and standard cancer treatment, had her tumor shrinked and her life expectancy extended.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Isabelle Bevier started the Home Economics program with an emphasis on scientific research and health. In 1900, Bevier created the Home Economics Program essentially from scratch, having no precedent to look to. With this freedom, she created a program that focused on the health aspects of home economics and nutrition. Part of that research helped Bevier figure out the idea to use a thermometer to promote safe cooking of meat, applying key aspects of chemistry to promote food safety. To do this, she worked in tandem with the Department of Animal Husbandry.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Karen Dina Tabb created the IDEA coalition in 2017  to improve maternal mental health awareness by identifying risk factors during the perinatal period. In 2018, Tabb and her team obtained funding from the Patient-Centered Outcomes Research Institute (PCORI) to create an advisory board to engage local people. The IDEA coalition quickly gained ground, hosting a national symposium in 2019, a mental-health film screening in both 2018 and 2019, and many other meetings. By this past spring (2020), the coalition received four funding awards to maintain their research, which they do along with students, faculty, and patients. The IDEA Coalition expanded to rural areas to help every population with perinatal depression.

vTarget.nodeDescription: For the last decade, the Krannert Center has been hosting the Dance for People with Parkinson's, a program that invites those with Parkinson's to come together to dance and move their bodies. This program works to provide those with Parkinson's to embrace their body movements in a judgement free zone, combining health with dance and music. The dancers go at their own pace and utilize the space in ways that their ability can afford them to. Regardless of their range of motion, there is a joyful mood surrounding the class, as it creates a space for people to embrace the music and temporarily step away from Parkinson's and to promote both physical and mental health habits.

vSource.nodeDescription: The department of Special Education created the Early Intervention Training Program to help train providers to help parents and children with disabilities. This program was created to help create skills for those with disabilities and their family to create a healthier atmosphere. This places an emphasis on education and life skills for future use. This provides a spot for providers the opportunity to learn new skills and strategies to help their families and others around them. The chance to learn skills creates a healthy life and starts with early intervention to foster a great lifestyle.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Node descriptionSometimes an innovation can be used for multiple purposes, some not even imagined while creating it. The electrostatic gyroscope was created at the University of Illinois by Howard Knoebel. The electrostatic gyroscope was initially invented to be used in submarines - which needed an instrument that would not need to be calibrated since it would be submerged for up to 30 days at a time. This device though would later be used in satellites to help them navigate space.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Dr. Robert Wilhemson was the first to create a digital animation of a thunderstorm (it was even nominated for an Academy Award in 1989 and won 14 other awards). He later developed an animation of a tornado forming from a thunderstorm. These technological advancements led to a new process to help with storm predictions. Computer models are now widely used to help understand storm movements.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Tony Wong Large Magellanic Cloud to look at star formation
vTarget.nodeDescription: Astronomy professor Tony Wong and a group of researchers were able to map how stars are born in the nearest star-forming galaxy. Wong and his team hope to use this information to understand our own galaxy. Wong used the Large Magellanic Cloud (nearby galaxy) to study, as it it tilted face-on. This tilt makes it easier for astronomers to study star formation. Based on what they are able to see, they decided to focus on molecular clouds as a base for star formation. They used a telescope in Australia to look at the Large Magellanic Cloud straight on to view those molecular clouds.

vSource.nodeDescription: Arthur N. Talbot created a railroad spiral in 1899, which enabled trains to move up a level to decrease wear and tear and make the travel more comfortable for passengers. The transitional spiral was essentially a math problem that many people developed independently, with Talbot perfecting the spiral in 1899. He was a Professor of Municipal and Sanitary Engineering (now housed within the Civil and Environmental Engineering department) who contributed his mathematical and engineering skills to make railroad trips more comfortable and more efficient, as railway travel was predominant in the late 19th century.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Text: The Vermillion River Observatory was constructed thanks to the work of George Swenson, a professor of astronomy and electrical engineering. Swenson was in charge of creating an interdisciplinary program in radio astronomy research. The telescopes (a model of which is found in the case) helped scientists catalog interstellar data. They then used this data to analyze the molecular structure of interstellar gas.

vTarget.nodeDescription:
i. Measuring a star’s brightness would take hours of observation and calculations. Astronomy professor Joel Stebbins in collaboration with physics professors F.C. Brown and Jakob Kunz would develop the photoelectric photometer which would use electricity to help simplify this process. 
 
 ii. Stebbins credited his wife as the driving force for this idea. When they were first married she would sometimes go to the observatory with him to help him get his work done faster so they could spend more time together. He told her one day they would be able to do this much faster with electricity and from then on she encouraged him to discover this method. A couple of months later he went to a physics open house where F.C. Brown had a demonstration of a selenium cell. Stebbins worked with Brown to create a selenium cell photometer.
 
 iii. While the selenium cell photometer helped discover five new eclipsing binary stars, Stebbins felt it was not strong enough. He was introduced to Jakob Kunz, who had been working to improve photoelectric cells. They collaborated to create and continually refine the photoelectric photometer. This development allowed for stebbins to better research variable stars and he was able to measure diameters and masses more accurately than any other instrument had been able to provide up to that point.

vSource.nodeDescription: Arthur N. Talbot created a railroad spiral in 1899, which enabled trains to move up a level to decrease wear and tear and make the travel more comfortable for passengers. The transitional spiral was essentially a math problem that many people developed independently, with Talbot perfecting the spiral in 1899. He was a Professor of Municipal and Sanitary Engineering (now housed within the Civil and Environmental Engineering department) who contributed his mathematical and engineering skills to make railroad trips more comfortable and more efficient, as railway travel was predominant in the late 19th century.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Node descriptionSometimes an innovation can be used for multiple purposes, some not even imagined while creating it. The electrostatic gyroscope was created at the University of Illinois by Howard Knoebel. The electrostatic gyroscope was initially invented to be used in submarines - which needed an instrument that would not need to be calibrated since it would be submerged for up to 30 days at a time. This device though would later be used in satellites to help them navigate space.

nodeAttributes.Photograph: photo on distributed museum website from book Men and Ideas in Engineering

vSource.nodeDescription: Arthur N. Talbot created a railroad spiral in 1899, which enabled trains to move up a level to decrease wear and tear and make the travel more comfortable for passengers. The transitional spiral was essentially a math problem that many people developed independently, with Talbot perfecting the spiral in 1899. He was a Professor of Municipal and Sanitary Engineering (now housed within the Civil and Environmental Engineering department) who contributed his mathematical and engineering skills to make railroad trips more comfortable and more efficient, as railway travel was predominant in the late 19th century.

nodeAttributes.Possible object: Image of Spiral (or 3d print of it?)
nodeAttributes.Observations: Rails Investigastion file in archives?

vTarget.nodeDescription: Today, the University of Illinois continues its interdisciplinary and collaborative approach to astronomy. One current project is the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope. This project is an international collaboration with the telescope located in Chile and the data being stored in Champaign Urbana. The National Center for Supercomputing Applications will store the 10 years worth of data, collecting about 20 terabytes of image data a night beginning in 2023. The data will be processed into reports as well as alerting researchers in near-real time of new and unexpected astronomical events.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Dr. Robert Wilhemson was the first to create a digital animation of a thunderstorm (it was even nominated for an Academy Award in 1989 and won 14 other awards). He later developed an animation of a tornado forming from a thunderstorm. These technological advancements led to a new process to help with storm predictions. Computer models are now widely used to help understand storm movements.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Tracking Sputnik I's Orbit with minitrack inferometer
vTarget.nodeDescription: George Swenson obtained the minitrack inferometer for members of the Illinois Astronomical Society to track Sputnik I's orbit on October 4, 1957. On the night in question, the inferometer was able to get measurements of Sputnik and were able to use Doppler Radar data. Members of the department used the data from the Doppler and inferometer to study its orbit. This data helped advance sateillite-based astronomical research and was helped with grants from the National Research Council, NASA, and the Air Force.

vTarget.nodeLabel: IMAX "A Beautiful Planet" with help from NCSA
vTarget.nodeDescription: The Ebert Symposium showed the film "A Beautiful Planet," which the NCSA helped create. The filmmakers collaborated with NCSA to create the opening and closing scenes of virtual intergalactic flight. The NCSA was able to create these scenes through scientific research. This film was shown as part of the "Empathy for the Universe: Storytelling and Data Visualization" tribute to Roger Ebert, a UIUC alum. This tribute also included an interview with astronaut Terry Virts and a variety of professors and alumni that discussed science data visualization in film.

vTarget.nodeDescription: As greenhouse gases and carbon dioxide continue to increase in our atmosphere, there has been much research done on what the possible impacts will be to our food supply. A multidisciplinary team at the University of Illinois was the first to conduct outdoor research on the effects of increased carbon dioxide on crops in a project called the Soybean Free Air Concentration Enrichment (SoyFACE). Previous studies have grown crops inside greenhouses to study what the changes in atmosphere may entail. For SoyFACE, Llarge octagonal plots are established with the ability to release higher concentrations of carbon dioxide and ozone on any side of the plot. This helps account for wind carrying the gases across the plot. This innovative way allows for crops to be grown with typical conditions but with future atmospheric conditions.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Professor Emma Mercier and her research team created a new app called "Food for Thought" which tells children about the carbon footprint created by the food they eat. The app tells the nutritional data along with the carbon footprint. Mercier's goal is twofold: to help children be more "data literate" and learn more about the causes of climate change. To do this research, Mercier and her team videotaped children learning about climate change and their food carbon footprint. The focus on food was to look at what children have more control over, which makes climate change awareness and learning more accessible.

vTarget.nodeLabel: William Fry and an ultrasound for non-invasive surgeries
vTarget.nodeDescription: William Fry, a professor in the eletrical engineering apartment, pioneered the ultrasound for use in non-invasive surgeries. He built his ultrasound equipment specifically to study how ultrasounds would effect animal tissue. His research led to its use on woman with late stage breast cancer, trying it out on five different woman. What makes this interesting is that one of the women lived twenty month longer after doing the ultrasound procedure. Along with his study on late stage breast cancer, he used the ultrasound technology to study the nervous system. A man of many talents, he also worked with his brother to create an artificial heart, keeping a dog alive for nine hours with the artificial heart!

vTarget.nodeLabel: Using Fitness Trackers in research to monitor health
vTarget.nodeDescription: Dr. Ruby Mendenhall is a jack of all trades, conducting research in various disciplines, all of which focus on black women and poverty and inequality. One of her focuses is on how stress based on gun violence would affect the genomes of black woman. Mendenhall and her team took blood samples to help create a fitness tracker. She worked with other departments, including the NCSA to help track black women's lives and history. In this case, Mendenhall is looking at "health" with regards to historical and cultural issues, calling on a wide range of experts to help her with her research.

vTarget.nodeDescription: The iBioFab Maker lab at the University of Illinois (as part of the Carle College of Medicine) has done research on how to create a device to detect cancer biomarkers. The current process is a needle biopsy to determine the cancer biomarker, a system that the research team is trying to perfect into a device that uses blood instead of the needle biopsy. The team created a new type of microscope to help make the test easy and and more efficient to perform. This was a collaboration between the engineers and the doctors, showing the power of interdisciplinary research.

nodeAttributes.College: Carle College of Medicine, iBioLab, Grainger College of Engineering
nodeAttributes.Current Faculty research: Brian T. Cunningham, Yi Lu, Rebecca Smith

vSource.nodeDescription: Wilbur Wilson, a professor of Civil Engineering and a member of the Illinois Steel Company, was a proponent of the rigid frame bridge. A rigid frame bridge was the popular design of the 1920s and was simply made of one piece of reinforced concrete. This idea was created to resist bending and tears, and, was cheaper to construct and maintain than previous types of bridges. Wilson's contribution to the rigid frame bridge was the concept that bolts would be better than rivets for the construction of the bridge. Linked to his interest in nuts and bolts, Wilson also helped in the creation of the Research Council on Riveted and Bolt Joints, putting his theory into practice.

nodeAttributes.Observations: Also: https://distributedmuseum.illinois.edu/exhibit/wilbur_m_wilson/

vTarget.nodeDescription: Text: The Vermillion River Observatory was constructed thanks to the work of George Swenson, a professor of astronomy and electrical engineering. Swenson was in charge of creating an interdisciplinary program in radio astronomy research. The telescopes (a model of which is found in the case) helped scientists catalog interstellar data. They then used this data to analyze the molecular structure of interstellar gas.

vTarget.nodeDescription:
i. Measuring a star’s brightness would take hours of observation and calculations. Astronomy professor Joel Stebbins in collaboration with physics professors F.C. Brown and Jakob Kunz would develop the photoelectric photometer which would use electricity to help simplify this process. 
 
 ii. Stebbins credited his wife as the driving force for this idea. When they were first married she would sometimes go to the observatory with him to help him get his work done faster so they could spend more time together. He told her one day they would be able to do this much faster with electricity and from then on she encouraged him to discover this method. A couple of months later he went to a physics open house where F.C. Brown had a demonstration of a selenium cell. Stebbins worked with Brown to create a selenium cell photometer.
 
 iii. While the selenium cell photometer helped discover five new eclipsing binary stars, Stebbins felt it was not strong enough. He was introduced to Jakob Kunz, who had been working to improve photoelectric cells. They collaborated to create and continually refine the photoelectric photometer. This development allowed for stebbins to better research variable stars and he was able to measure diameters and masses more accurately than any other instrument had been able to provide up to that point.

vSource.nodeDescription: Karl B. Lohmann, professor of Landscape Architecture, taught one of the earliest courses in regional planning. Regional planning is the focus on the organization of communities and areas for a large piece of land rather than a city or town. This is a different type of planning that utilizes different space and types of land usage. This course and thought method (?) also included a variety of people to help Lohmann with his lectures, including Henry Wright (town planner) and T.F. Frison (conservationist). This concept combines the ideas of urban planning with a natural approach to larger areas of land, as he aimed to teach his students about the planning on a larger scale than just urban planning.

nodeAttributes.College: College of Fine and Applied Arts

vTarget.nodeLabel: Tony Wong Large Magellanic Cloud to look at star formation
vTarget.nodeDescription: Astronomy professor Tony Wong and a group of researchers were able to map how stars are born in the nearest star-forming galaxy. Wong and his team hope to use this information to understand our own galaxy. Wong used the Large Magellanic Cloud (nearby galaxy) to study, as it it tilted face-on. This tilt makes it easier for astronomers to study star formation. Based on what they are able to see, they decided to focus on molecular clouds as a base for star formation. They used a telescope in Australia to look at the Large Magellanic Cloud straight on to view those molecular clouds.

nodeAttributes.Possible object: telescope or LMC (LMC image in link)

vTarget.nodeDescription: The University of Illinois has been studying the relationship between nature and humans since its earliest days. From 1884 to 1921, Stephen Forbes was a professor in zoology and entomology who mostly studied insects, birds, fish and crustaceans. His major area of focus was the interactions between species and how these interactions affected the agricultural industry. His publications were some of the earliest work in what is now known as the field of ecology and he is considered as one of the founders of the formal field. Looking at how animals and humans have an impact on each other’s environments, habits, and culture is also an important part of climate change research currently taking place.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Global Warming effects on the Houma Tribe (Shanondora Billiot’s research)
vTarget.nodeDescription: Shanondora BIllet went to Louisiana's Gulf Coast to interview members from the United Houma Nation to look at how the destruction of the coast has affected their lives and worldview. After being vetted by leaders of the tribe, BIllet was able to see that the tribe, which makes its living via the water (fishing, shrimping, trapping, etc.) and had to change how they made their living. With the new changes to the coast and to the water, older members of the Houma tribe find it difficult to pass on their traditions to youngermembers, causing distress. This climate change and destruction of the coast has caused a nation to reevaluate their way of life and their traditions.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Religious Figures talking about climate change: StewardshipNode name
vTarget.nodeDescription: Psychology graduate student Faith Shin conducted research on how different messages within Christianity were linked to how people viewed and responded to climate change. Shin found that messages linked to stewardship (God commands humans to take care of the Earth) often resulted in Christians viewing climate change concern as a moral imperative. This is compared to dominion beliefs, which advocate for the idea that God gives humans free reign. Dominion beliefs are linked tot lower concerncocnern for climate change. Shin conducted this research through having different groups read different articles including: Bible passages (either stewardship or dominion) or a control article. An interesting find is that while the stewardship articles showed an increase inmore moral concern about climate change, the dominion articles did not reduce moral concerns.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Deke Weaver's art on tigers and effect of climate change
vTarget.nodeDescription: Deke Weaver, professor of new media, created and starred in a show called TIGER from a five-part series called "The Unreliable Bestiary." In this show and this series, Weaver talks about famous tigers, such as Tony the Tiger and the tigers from the Jungle Book, as well as how humans interact with tigers. This was created to call attention to climate change and how it affects wildlife. To further comment on this, Weaver performed the show along the Mississippi River and its watershed to comment on migration as a result of climate change.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Professor Emma Mercier and her research team created a new app called "Food for Thought" which tells children about the carbon footprint created by the food they eat. The app tells the nutritional data along with the carbon footprint. Mercier's goal is twofold: to help children be more "data literate" and learn more about the causes of climate change. To do this research, Mercier and her team videotaped children learning about climate change and their food carbon footprint. The focus on food was to look at what children have more control over, which makes climate change awareness and learning more accessible.

vTarget.nodeLabel: "Other Natures" book about Ancient Greek ethnographies
vTarget.nodeDescription: Professor Clara Bosak-Schroder looks at ethnographies written by Herodotus and Diodorus to see how their works look in the context of current climate change issues. These ethnographies (ancient travelogues) look at differences in consumption, something that is more relevant now as we look to different things to eat in the wake of a changing climate. Bosak-Schroder thinks that these ethnographies can help current leaders find ways to view and fix climate change issues. She also focuses on how people are educated about climate issues, which is another way that these ancient words can help influence modern thinking.

vTarget.nodeDescription: The Earth's critical zone is it's "living skin" that, when studied, looks at how different processes on Earth interact. Praveen Kumar does research on hydrology and its different processes. The critical zone helps us understand how interactions between water, air, life, and rock can be affected by human behavior. More specifically, the critical zone looks at how changing the Earth's surface can affect subsurface processes including waterflow and elements. Kumar's research into water is a key aspect of looking at the critical zone and it's link to climate change.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Node nameThreonine and William C. Rose
vTarget.nodeDescription: Rose discovered the amino acid Threonine and that amino acids are required in our diets after studying amino acids in rats' diets. Rose found in the 1930s that rats, when fed a variety of amino acids, would die until they ingested "casein" in milk. Rose, figuring that casein included an essential amino acid to life, eventually discovered threonine. After this initial research, Rose moved on to human diets, feeding male graduate students with the essential amino acids. This research was awared the National Medal of Science in biological sciences in 1966. So, we ought to thank William C. Rose for helping us know what food is best for us!

vTarget.nodeDescription: Dr. Timothy Nugent, a professor Rehabilitation Education, pioneered the National Wheelchair Basketball Association in 1949. He created this league to help destigmatize those with disabilities, aiming to change the societal and cultural views towards disability. This idea initially began after World War II, where Nugent found it necessary to create programs for wounded veterans. Nugent's league eventually included both men's and women's teams that played in the Olympics in 1968, and can still be seen playing here at the University, maintaining Nugent's original view of a destigmatized sport.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Isabelle Bevier started the Home Economics program with an emphasis on scientific research and health. In 1900, Bevier created the Home Economics Program essentially from scratch, having no precedent to look to. With this freedom, she created a program that focused on the health aspects of home economics and nutrition. Part of that research helped Bevier figure out the idea to use a thermometer to promote safe cooking of meat, applying key aspects of chemistry to promote food safety. To do this, she worked in tandem with the Department of Animal Husbandry.

nodeAttributes.Observations: Lots of stuff in archives...worth a look; here's another link: https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/84903192.pdf

vTarget.nodeDescription: For the last decade, the Krannert Center has been hosting the Dance for People with Parkinson's, a program that invites those with Parkinson's to come together to dance and move their bodies. This program works to provide those with Parkinson's to embrace their body movements in a judgement free zone, combining health with dance and music. The dancers go at their own pace and utilize the space in ways that their ability can afford them to. Regardless of their range of motion, there is a joyful mood surrounding the class, as it creates a space for people to embrace the music and temporarily step away from Parkinson's and to promote both physical and mental health habits.

nodeAttributes.College: College of Fine and Applied Arts

vSource.nodeLabel: Beverly L. Greene: 1st African-American Woman to earn a BS in architectural engineering
vSource.nodeDescription: Beverly Loraine Greene was the first African American woman to earn a Bachelors of Science in architectural engineering from UIUC in 1936. Continuing her education, she received a Masters degree in city planning and housing before returning to her home Chicago in 1938 to pursue a career in the Chicago Housing Authority. Greene was one of the first African Americans to work for the Chicago Housing Authority, as she continued to break down barriers. Her achievements in architecture included a housing project in the Stuyvesant neighborhood in New York City, the UNESCO United Nations headquarters in Paris, and she began work on buildings for New York University prior to her death in 1957.

nodeAttributes.Observations: Awesome person achieving cool stuff?

vTarget.nodeLabel: Tony Wong Large Magellanic Cloud to look at star formation
vTarget.nodeDescription: Astronomy professor Tony Wong and a group of researchers were able to map how stars are born in the nearest star-forming galaxy. Wong and his team hope to use this information to understand our own galaxy. Wong used the Large Magellanic Cloud (nearby galaxy) to study, as it it tilted face-on. This tilt makes it easier for astronomers to study star formation. Based on what they are able to see, they decided to focus on molecular clouds as a base for star formation. They used a telescope in Australia to look at the Large Magellanic Cloud straight on to view those molecular clouds.

vSource.nodeLabel: Beverly L. Greene: 1st African-American Woman to earn a BS in architectural engineering
vSource.nodeDescription: Beverly Loraine Greene was the first African American woman to earn a Bachelors of Science in architectural engineering from UIUC in 1936. Continuing her education, she received a Masters degree in city planning and housing before returning to her home Chicago in 1938 to pursue a career in the Chicago Housing Authority. Greene was one of the first African Americans to work for the Chicago Housing Authority, as she continued to break down barriers. Her achievements in architecture included a housing project in the Stuyvesant neighborhood in New York City, the UNESCO United Nations headquarters in Paris, and she began work on buildings for New York University prior to her death in 1957.

nodeAttributes.Observations: Awesome person achieving cool stuff?

vTarget.nodeLabel: Node nameThreonine and William C. Rose
vTarget.nodeDescription: Rose discovered the amino acid Threonine and that amino acids are required in our diets after studying amino acids in rats' diets. Rose found in the 1930s that rats, when fed a variety of amino acids, would die until they ingested "casein" in milk. Rose, figuring that casein included an essential amino acid to life, eventually discovered threonine. After this initial research, Rose moved on to human diets, feeding male graduate students with the essential amino acids. This research was awared the National Medal of Science in biological sciences in 1966. So, we ought to thank William C. Rose for helping us know what food is best for us!

nodeAttributes.Observations: Have to find this research from Illinois publications
nodeAttributes.Current Faculty research: Hans H. Stein has done a version of this research with regards to pig diets (Animal Sciences)

vTarget.nodeDescription: Dr. Timothy Nugent, a professor Rehabilitation Education, pioneered the National Wheelchair Basketball Association in 1949. He created this league to help destigmatize those with disabilities, aiming to change the societal and cultural views towards disability. This idea initially began after World War II, where Nugent found it necessary to create programs for wounded veterans. Nugent's league eventually included both men's and women's teams that played in the Olympics in 1968, and can still be seen playing here at the University, maintaining Nugent's original view of a destigmatized sport.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Isabelle Bevier started the Home Economics program with an emphasis on scientific research and health. In 1900, Bevier created the Home Economics Program essentially from scratch, having no precedent to look to. With this freedom, she created a program that focused on the health aspects of home economics and nutrition. Part of that research helped Bevier figure out the idea to use a thermometer to promote safe cooking of meat, applying key aspects of chemistry to promote food safety. To do this, she worked in tandem with the Department of Animal Husbandry.

vTarget.nodeDescription: For the last decade, the Krannert Center has been hosting the Dance for People with Parkinson's, a program that invites those with Parkinson's to come together to dance and move their bodies. This program works to provide those with Parkinson's to embrace their body movements in a judgement free zone, combining health with dance and music. The dancers go at their own pace and utilize the space in ways that their ability can afford them to. Regardless of their range of motion, there is a joyful mood surrounding the class, as it creates a space for people to embrace the music and temporarily step away from Parkinson's and to promote both physical and mental health habits.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Karl B. Lohmann, professor of Landscape Architecture, taught one of the earliest courses in regional planning. Regional planning is the focus on the organization of communities and areas for a large piece of land rather than a city or town. This is a different type of planning that utilizes different space and types of land usage. This course and thought method (?) also included a variety of people to help Lohmann with his lectures, including Henry Wright (town planner) and T.F. Frison (conservationist). This concept combines the ideas of urban planning with a natural approach to larger areas of land, as he aimed to teach his students about the planning on a larger scale than just urban planning.

vSource.nodeDescription: Research Residence No. 1, located at 1108 W. Stoughton St in Urbana, Il, was built in 1924 as a collaboration between UIUC and the National Warm Air Heating and Ventilating Association to research heating in private homes. The team conducted many experiments to test out different heating systems. This would be a trial and error system to determine what heating system should be kept or scrapped. This residence was a hands-on and real time experiment to see how heating and different materials would work in a home. The success of Research Residence No. 1 led to the creation of other research homes.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Text: The Vermillion River Observatory was constructed thanks to the work of George Swenson, a professor of astronomy and electrical engineering. Swenson was in charge of creating an interdisciplinary program in radio astronomy research. The telescopes (a model of which is found in the case) helped scientists catalog interstellar data. They then used this data to analyze the molecular structure of interstellar gas.

vTarget.nodeDescription:
i. Measuring a star’s brightness would take hours of observation and calculations. Astronomy professor Joel Stebbins in collaboration with physics professors F.C. Brown and Jakob Kunz would develop the photoelectric photometer which would use electricity to help simplify this process. 
 
 ii. Stebbins credited his wife as the driving force for this idea. When they were first married she would sometimes go to the observatory with him to help him get his work done faster so they could spend more time together. He told her one day they would be able to do this much faster with electricity and from then on she encouraged him to discover this method. A couple of months later he went to a physics open house where F.C. Brown had a demonstration of a selenium cell. Stebbins worked with Brown to create a selenium cell photometer.
 
 iii. While the selenium cell photometer helped discover five new eclipsing binary stars, Stebbins felt it was not strong enough. He was introduced to Jakob Kunz, who had been working to improve photoelectric cells. They collaborated to create and continually refine the photoelectric photometer. This development allowed for stebbins to better research variable stars and he was able to measure diameters and masses more accurately than any other instrument had been able to provide up to that point.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Node descriptionSometimes an innovation can be used for multiple purposes, some not even imagined while creating it. The electrostatic gyroscope was created at the University of Illinois by Howard Knoebel. The electrostatic gyroscope was initially invented to be used in submarines - which needed an instrument that would not need to be calibrated since it would be submerged for up to 30 days at a time. This device though would later be used in satellites to help them navigate space.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Today, the University of Illinois continues its interdisciplinary and collaborative approach to astronomy. One current project is the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope. This project is an international collaboration with the telescope located in Chile and the data being stored in Champaign Urbana. The National Center for Supercomputing Applications will store the 10 years worth of data, collecting about 20 terabytes of image data a night beginning in 2023. The data will be processed into reports as well as alerting researchers in near-real time of new and unexpected astronomical events.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Dr. Robert Wilhemson was the first to create a digital animation of a thunderstorm (it was even nominated for an Academy Award in 1989 and won 14 other awards). He later developed an animation of a tornado forming from a thunderstorm. These technological advancements led to a new process to help with storm predictions. Computer models are now widely used to help understand storm movements.

vTarget.nodeLabel: Tracking Sputnik I's Orbit with minitrack inferometer
vTarget.nodeDescription: George Swenson obtained the minitrack inferometer for members of the Illinois Astronomical Society to track Sputnik I's orbit on October 4, 1957. On the night in question, the inferometer was able to get measurements of Sputnik and were able to use Doppler Radar data. Members of the department used the data from the Doppler and inferometer to study its orbit. This data helped advance sateillite-based astronomical research and was helped with grants from the National Research Council, NASA, and the Air Force.

vTarget.nodeLabel: IMAX "A Beautiful Planet" with help from NCSA
vTarget.nodeDescription: The Ebert Symposium showed the film "A Beautiful Planet," which the NCSA helped create. The filmmakers collaborated with NCSA to create the opening and closing scenes of virtual intergalactic flight. The NCSA was able to create these scenes through scientific research. This film was shown as part of the "Empathy for the Universe: Storytelling and Data Visualization" tribute to Roger Ebert, a UIUC alum. This tribute also included an interview with astronaut Terry Virts and a variety of professors and alumni that discussed science data visualization in film.

vTarget.nodeDescription: As greenhouse gases and carbon dioxide continue to increase in our atmosphere, there has been much research done on what the possible impacts will be to our food supply. A multidisciplinary team at the University of Illinois was the first to conduct outdoor research on the effects of increased carbon dioxide on crops in a project called the Soybean Free Air Concentration Enrichment (SoyFACE). Previous studies have grown crops inside greenhouses to study what the changes in atmosphere may entail. For SoyFACE, Llarge octagonal plots are established with the ability to release higher concentrations of carbon dioxide and ozone on any side of the plot. This helps account for wind carrying the gases across the plot. This innovative way allows for crops to be grown with typical conditions but with future atmospheric conditions.

nodeAttributes.College: ACES/ LAS/ School of Integrative biology/ Institute for Genomic Biology
nodeAttributes.Department: Plant Biology, crop sciences; agricultural and biological engineering; integrative biology, Natural Resources and envirnomental sciences

vTarget.nodeDescription: Professor Emma Mercier and her research team created a new app called "Food for Thought" which tells children about the carbon footprint created by the food they eat. The app tells the nutritional data along with the carbon footprint. Mercier's goal is twofold: to help children be more "data literate" and learn more about the causes of climate change. To do this research, Mercier and her team videotaped children learning about climate change and their food carbon footprint. The focus on food was to look at what children have more control over, which makes climate change awareness and learning more accessible.

vTarget.nodeLabel: William Fry and an ultrasound for non-invasive surgeries
vTarget.nodeDescription: William Fry, a professor in the eletrical engineering apartment, pioneered the ultrasound for use in non-invasive surgeries. He built his ultrasound equipment specifically to study how ultrasounds would effect animal tissue. His research led to its use on woman with late stage breast cancer, trying it out on five different woman. What makes this interesting is that one of the women lived twenty month longer after doing the ultrasound procedure. Along with his study on late stage breast cancer, he used the ultrasound technology to study the nervous system. A man of many talents, he also worked with his brother to create an artificial heart, keeping a dog alive for nine hours with the artificial heart!

vTarget.nodeLabel: Using Fitness Trackers in research to monitor health
vTarget.nodeDescription: Dr. Ruby Mendenhall is a jack of all trades, conducting research in various disciplines, all of which focus on black women and poverty and inequality. One of her focuses is on how stress based on gun violence would affect the genomes of black woman. Mendenhall and her team took blood samples to help create a fitness tracker. She worked with other departments, including the NCSA to help track black women's lives and history. In this case, Mendenhall is looking at "health" with regards to historical and cultural issues, calling on a wide range of experts to help her with her research.

vTarget.nodeDescription: The iBioFab Maker lab at the University of Illinois (as part of the Carle College of Medicine) has done research on how to create a device to detect cancer biomarkers. The current process is a needle biopsy to determine the cancer biomarker, a system that the research team is trying to perfect into a device that uses blood instead of the needle biopsy. The team created a new type of microscope to help make the test easy and and more efficient to perform. This was a collaboration between the engineers and the doctors, showing the power of interdisciplinary research.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Arthur N. Talbot created a railroad spiral in 1899, which enabled trains to move up a level to decrease wear and tear and make the travel more comfortable for passengers. The transitional spiral was essentially a math problem that many people developed independently, with Talbot perfecting the spiral in 1899. He was a Professor of Municipal and Sanitary Engineering (now housed within the Civil and Environmental Engineering department) who contributed his mathematical and engineering skills to make railroad trips more comfortable and more efficient, as railway travel was predominant in the late 19th century.

vTarget.nodeDescription: Wilbur Wilson, a professor of Civil Engineering and a member of the Illinois Steel Company, was a proponent of the rigid frame bridge. A rigid frame bridge was the popular design of the 1920s and was simply made of one piece of reinforced concrete. This idea was created to resist bending and tears, and, was cheaper to construct and maintain than previous types of bridges. Wilson's contribution to the rigid frame bridge was the concept that bolts would be better than rivets for the construction of the bridge. Linked to his interest in nuts and bolts, Wilson also helped in the creation of the Research Council on Riveted and Bolt Joints, putting his theory into practice.
